fields.summary:
The Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) is a special type of account which allows Canadian residents to contribute after-tax funds up to a yearly contribution limit. Any earnings within the TFSA account (such as interest or capital gains) are tax-free. The individual can choose to withdraw funds from his/her TFSA at any time without being subject to tax on the withdrawals.
The Conservative government has proposed to dobule the TFSA contribution limit from the current $5,500 per year to $11,000 per year.

fields.title: Athebasca River water usage legislation
fields.text:
"The challenge we have is that we're using what I'd call the best available science," said Andy Ridge, director of water policy for Alberta Environment. "It's not necessarily the best possible. [1]

Last December, the provincial government distributed its draft surface water quantity management framework for the Lower Athabasca River to industry, interest groups and First Nations. Its measures are expected to be implemented by the fall. [1]

The report points out industrial water demand on the Athabasca is expected to increase by nearly 500 per cent by 2020 and provides ways to regulate how much water could be removed at different times of the year. The river's flow varies wildly: from 88 cubic metres per second in January to more than 3,500 in July. [1]

Using 50 years of flow data, the report lays out varying withdrawal limits for five "seasons." At all times, total withdrawals would be a small fraction of the river's flow and would nearly stop when the Athabasca was flowing at its lowest rate. [1]

Ridge acknowledges in-the-field science is scarce in the report. He said Alberta used state-of-the-art computer modelling to fill in the gap. [1]


The problem, say critics, is that there's no research justifying those withdrawals. Fish habitat, bug populations, water quality, groundwater, connections to tributaries -- none of those factors was considered. [1]

 Even a couple inches in water levels can be critical, said Schindler. [1]

"The main fear about low flows is that it will leave eggs and embryos high and dry. It's like nobody wants to get out into the field and do some actual biology to see what flows the (plants and animals) require." [1]

"The science is less in the actual looking at the trends in the flows and more in the running of scenarios -- using raw data from different sources and running through models that are generally accepted water models." [1]

"When we hit low water levels, a lot of our people won't even be able to get into their traditional territory," said Chief Allan Adam of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation, a band of 1,000 people at Fort Chipewyan, where about three-quarters of the people are on the river several times a week.[1]

Adam's band has filed for a judicial review of a land-use plan for the area that includes the water-use framework.[1]

Oilsands operators used approximately 170 million cubic meters of water in 2011, equivalent to the residential water use of 1.7 million Canadians. [2]


Oilsands mining operations are subject to a zero-discharge policy because of the toxins in the waste water. Waste water that is not recycled is stored in tailings lakes.
    Waste water from in-situ processes is often re-injected deep underground. [2]

# References #
[1] [CTV News, *Alberta's plan for Athabasca River 'pathetic,' not science-based: critics*](http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/alberta-s-plan-for-athabasca-river-pathetic-not-science-based-critics-1.1735778)
[2] [Pembina Institute, *Water Impacts*, 2013](http://www.pembina.org/oil-sands/os101/water#footnote3_iuh07fc
fields.summary: Both critics and scientists

fields.title: Athebasca River water usage legislation
fields.text:
# Actors #
 - *Andy Ridge* -- Director of water policy for Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development.
 - The Alberta Water Council is another important player, acting as an advisory board bringing stakeholders and experts together to oversee the implementation of the strategy
 - Allan Adams, Chief of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation
 - Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers
 - Oil Sands Leadership Initiative (OSLI) comprised of Suncor Energy Inc, ConocoPhillips Canada, Nexen Inc., Shell Canada Ltd., Statoil Canada and Total E+P Canada Ltd. initiated and advanced several improvements to water management practices.

# Background #


The Athebasca River
 - The river's flow varies wildly: from 88 cubic metres per second in January to more than 3,500 in July. [1]



Industrial water use and its effects
 - Industrial water demand on the Athabasca is expected to increase almost 5-fold by 2020. [1]
Oilsands operators used approximately 170 million cubic meters of water in 2011, equivalent to the residential water use of 1.7 million Canadians. [2]
 - Oilsands mining operations are subject to a zero-discharge policy because of the toxins in the waste water. Waste water that is not recycled is stored in tailings lakes.[2]
    Waste water from in-situ processes is often re-injected deep underground. [2]
- The Canadian Association of Petroleum Producer’s 2013 Crude Oil Forecast says oil production will jump from an average of 3.2 million barrels per day in 2012 to 6.7 million bpd by 2030.[3]
 - Daily freshwater use in 2022 is projected to be 4,861,389 barrels (772,900 cubic metres). [2]
 - The majority of the water used for mining is taken from the Athabasca River [2]

 - Water withdrawals during winter low-flow periods risk reducing the availability of fish habitat and could reduce the health of the river’s ecosystem.15,16 This is especially a risk for the Lower Athabasca River as the average discharge from the river's mouth into Lake Athabasca during low-flow periods was 30% less in 1996-2006 than it was in 1966-1976.17[2]


Alberta recently released new water framework
 - Last December, the provincial government distributed its draft surface water quantity management framework for the Lower Athabasca River to industry, interest groups and First Nations. [1]
 - The framework regulates how much water can be removed at different times of the year. [1]
 - Its measures are expected to be implemented by the fall. [1]
 - At all times, total withdrawals would be a small fraction of the river's flow and would nearly stop when the Athabasca was flowing at its lowest rate. [1]





The framework is being criticized for lack of scientific foundation

 - "The challenge we have is that we're using what I'd call the best available science," said Andy Ridge, director of water policy for Alberta Environment. "It's not necessarily the best possible. [1]
 - Ridge acknowledges in-the-field science is scarce in the report. He said Alberta used state-of-the-art computer modelling to fill in the gap. [1]
 - The problem, say critics, is that there's no research justifying those withdrawals. [1]
 - Fish habitat, bug populations, water quality, groundwater, connections to tributaries -- none of those factors was considered. [1]
 - Even a couple inches in water levels can be critical, said Schindler. [1]
 - "The main fear about low flows is that it will leave eggs and embryos high and dry. It's like nobody wants to get out into the field and do some actual biology to see what flows the (plants and animals) require." [1]


The report relies on computer simulations rather than field data
"The science is less in the actual looking at the trends in the flows and more in the running of scenarios -- using raw data from different sources and running through models that are generally accepted water models." [1]



 - We require industry to demonstrate that they are using the most appropriate source, namely that they’re going to the brackish or the saline groundwater before they use fresh groundwater and before they use fresh surface water,” Ridge says. [3]
 - This policy will put the onus on producers, particularly those involved in in-situ and hydraulic fracturing operations, to demonstrate that they have sourced, or exhausted all attempts to source, non-potable water and identified opportunities for water sharing and treatment before they are issued a license.



 - "When we hit low water levels, a lot of our people won't even be able to get into their traditional territory," said Chief Allan Adam of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation, a band of 1,000 people at Fort Chipewyan, where about three-quarters of the people are on the river several times a week.[1]

 - In Alberta’s north, water is abundant and demand is still relatively low and challenges have been managed. But in the southern portion of the province, the ratio of need to supply is the opposite and the province’s historical allocation regime has caused enough potential problems that the southern basin is now closed to granting new surface water licenses. [3]

 - Adam's band has filed for a judicial review of a land-use plan for the area that includes the water-use framework.[1]







# In perspective #
- In CAPP’s 2013 Crude Oil Forecast, oil sands production is projected to rise to 5.2 million bpd in 2030 from 1.8 million bpd in 2012.[3]



# References #
[1] [CTV News, *Alberta's plan for Athabasca River 'pathetic,' not science-based: critics*](http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/alberta-s-plan-for-athabasca-river-pathetic-not-science-based-critics-1.1735778)
[2] [Pembina Institute, *Water Impacts*, 2013](http://www.pembina.org/oil-sands/os101/water#footnote3_iuh07fc
[3] [Alberta Oil, *Alberta desperately needs a water-management plan*, 2013](http://www.albertaoilmagazine.com/2013/07/alberta-and-the-life-aquatic/)
fields.summary: Scientists criticize the Alberta's water management framework drafted in December 2014 for having little scientific basis.  The Director of water policy for Albertan Environment and Sustainable Resource Development admits that there is little empirical data available upon which to base the framework.

fields.title: Athebasca River water usage legislation
fields.text:
# Actors #
 - *Andy Ridge* -- Director of water policy for Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development.
 - The Alberta Water Council is another important player, acting as an advisory board bringing stakeholders and experts together to oversee the implementation of the strategy
 - Allan Adams, Chief of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation
 - Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers
 - Oil Sands Leadership Initiative (OSLI) comprised of Suncor Energy Inc, ConocoPhillips Canada, Nexen Inc., Shell Canada Ltd., Statoil Canada and Total E+P Canada Ltd. initiated and advanced several improvements to water management practices.



# Background #


The majority of the water used for extraction of petroleum from the Albertan oilsands is taken from the Athabasca River [2].

In 2011, oilsands operators used approximately 170 million cubic metres of water, equivalent to the residential water use of 1.7 million Canadians [2].
Industrial water demand on the Athabasca is expected to increase almost 5-fold by 2020. [1]
The Canadian Association of Petroleum Producer’s 2013 Crude Oil Forecast says oil production will jump from an average of 3.2 million barrels per day in 2012 to 6.7 million bpd by 2030.[3]
Daily freshwater use in 2022 is projected to be 4,861,389 barrels (772,900 cubic metres). [2]

Oilsands mining operations are subject to a zero-discharge policy because of the toxins in the waste water. This means that the water that is used in petroleum extraction cannot be returned to its source.  Waste water that is not recycled is stored in tailings lakes or is injected deep underground. [2]

In Alberta’s north, water is abundant and demand is still relatively low and challenges have been managed. But in the southern portion of the province, the ratio of need to supply is the opposite and the province’s historical allocation regime has caused enough potential problems that the southern basin is now closed to granting new surface water licenses. [3]

This is especially a risk for the Lower Athabasca River as the average discharge from the river's mouth into Lake Athabasca during low-flow periods was 30% less in 1996-2006 than it was in 1966-1976.[2]




 - Flow downstream of Fort McMurray is predicted to decrease by 30 per cent by 2050, due to the combined impacts of climate change and industrial water withdrawals

Water withdrawals during winter low-flow periods risk reducing the availability of fish habitat and could reduce the health of the river’s ecosystem.

 - Independent research suggests concentrations of dissolved polycyclic aromatic compounds (PAC) are higher downstream of oilsands development, in comparison to upstream, in tributaries to the Athabasca. This trend is more pronounced in the summer than in the winter.24
 - Independent research has also found that sediment of lakes in the oilsands region (including one lake approximately 90 kilometres from the major development area) contain between 2.5 and 23 times higher concentrations of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) than they did 50 years ago, before the industrial development of the oilsands began.25




 - Fish habitat, bug populations, water quality, groundwater, connections to tributaries -- none of those factors was considered. [1]
 - Even a couple inches in water levels can be critical, said Schindler. [1]
 - "The main fear about low flows is that it will leave eggs and embryos high and dry. It's like nobody wants to get out into the field and do some actual biology to see what flows the (plants and animals) require." [1]
 - "When we hit low water levels, a lot of our people won't even be able to get into their traditional territory," said Chief Allan Adam of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation, a band of 1,000 people at Fort Chipewyan, where about three-quarters of the people are on the river several times a week.[1]





Last December, the government of Alberta distributed a draft surface water quantity management framework for the Lower Athabasca River to industry, interest groups and First Nations. [1]
The framework regulates how much water can be removed at different times of the year. [1]
Its measures are expected to be implemented by fall 2015. [1]
At all times, total withdrawals would be a small fraction of the river's flow and would nearly stop when the Athabasca was flowing at its lowest rate. [1]





The framework is being heavily criticized for lack of scientific foundation.
Andy Ridge, director of water policy for Alberta Environment, acknowledges that the in-the-field science is scarce in the report. [1]
The framework relies on computer modelling to supplement the lack of empirical data. [1]
However, there is no research justifying the specific levels of withdrawals prescribed by the new water framework. [1]
In 2011, Environment Canada and a team of independent experts concluded that the current water monitoring system for the Athabasca region “did not deliver data of sufficient quantity or quality to detect or quantify the effects of oilsands development.”[2]





 - Fish habitat, bug populations, water quality, groundwater, connections to tributaries -- none of those factors was considered. [1]
 - Even a couple inches in water levels can be critical, said Schindler. [1]
 - "The main fear about low flows is that it will leave eggs and embryos high and dry. It's like nobody wants to get out into the field and do some actual biology to see what flows the (plants and animals) require." [1]




 - We require industry to demonstrate that they are using the most appropriate source, namely that they’re going to the brackish or the saline groundwater before they use fresh groundwater and before they use fresh surface water,” Ridge says. [3]
 - This policy will put the onus on producers, particularly those involved in in-situ and hydraulic fracturing operations, to demonstrate that they have sourced, or exhausted all attempts to source, non-potable water and identified opportunities for water sharing and treatment before they are issued a license.





 - Adam's band has filed for a judicial review of a land-use plan for the area that includes the water-use framework.[1]







# In perspective #
- In CAPP’s 2013 Crude Oil Forecast, oil sands production is projected to rise to 5.2 million bpd in 2030 from 1.8 million bpd in 2012.[3]



# References #
[1] [CTV News, *Alberta's plan for Athabasca River 'pathetic,' not science-based: critics*](http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/alberta-s-plan-for-athabasca-river-pathetic-not-science-based-critics-1.1735778)
[2] [Pembina Institute, *Water Impacts*, 2013](http://www.pembina.org/oil-sands/os101/water#footnote3_iuh07fc
[3] [Alberta Oil, *Alberta desperately needs a water-management plan*, 2013](http://www.albertaoilmagazine.com/2013/07/alberta-and-the-life-aquatic/)

fields.title: Athebasca River water usage legislation
fields.text:
# Actors #
 - **Andy Ridge** -- Director of water policy for Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development.
 - **The Alberta Water Council** -- acts as an advisory board bringing stakeholders and experts together to oversee the implementation of water management strategies.
 - **Allan Adams** -- Chief of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation.  The Chipewyan First Nation uses the Athebasca river extensively, with three-quarters of their community on the river multiple times per week.
 - **Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers (CAPP)** -- an industry group representing the oilsands industry in Canada.
 - **Oil Sands Leadership Initiative (OSLI)** -- six oilsands companies that have initiated and advanced several improvements to water management practices.  Includes Suncor Energy Inc, ConocoPhillips Canada, Nexen Inc., Shell Canada Ltd., Statoil Canada and Total E+P Canada Ltd.


# Background #

In December 2014, the government of Alberta distributed a draft surface water quantity management framework for the Lower Athabasca River to industry, interest groups and First Nations [1].

Most of the water used for extraction of petroleum from the Albertan oilsands is taken from the Athabasca River [2].  In 2011, oilsands operators used about 170 million cubic metres of water, which is equivalent to the amount of water used by 1.7 million Canadians [2].  This demand is expected to grow five-fold by 2020 [1].

Surface water that is taken for oilsands extraction cannot be returned because of the toxins in the waste water.  Some water can be recycled within the extraction process, but ultimately, the water taken in ends up as waste water which has to be stored in tailings ponds or injected deep underground [2].

In Alberta’s north, water is abundant and demand is still ``relatively low''. But in the southern portion of the province, demand is straining the existing allocation regime and the ecology.   The southern basin is now closed to granting new surface water licenses [3].
Average discharge from lower Athebasca River's mouth into Lake Athabasca during low-flow periods was 30% less in 1996-2006 than it was in 1966-1976 [2].  Flow downstream of Fort McMurray is predicted to decrease by 30 per cent by 2050, due to the combined impacts of climate change and industrial water withdrawals [2].





Water withdrawals during winter low-flow periods risk reducing the availability of fish habitat [1]. Reduction of water flow can destroy the conditions needed for viability of and developing embryos of aquatic species in the river [1]. Even a couple inches in water levels can be critical, said Schindler. [1]

The Athebasca River is used extensively by about 1000 people from the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation.  According to Chief Allan Adam [1]:

    When we hit low water levels, a lot of our people won't even be able to get into their 
    traditional territory

About three-quarters of the Chipewyan people are on the river several times a week [1].


In addition to affecting water levels, there is evidence that, despite the fact that water drawn from the river is not returned, industrial activity is nevertheless introducing harmful chemicals into the Athebasca River.
Independent research suggests concentrations of dissolved polycyclic aromatic compounds (PAC) are higher downstream of oilsands development, in comparison to upstream, in tributaries to the Athabasca [2]. 
This trend is more pronounced in the summer than in the winter [2].
Independent research has also found that sediment of lakes in the oilsands region (including one lake approximately 90 kilometres from the major development area) contain between 2.5 and 23 times higher concentrations of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) than they did 50 years ago, before the industrial development of the oilsands began [2]



The draft water management framework recently released by the government of Alberta would regulate how much water can be removed at different times of the year [1].
Its measures are expected to be implemented by fall 2015 [1].
At all times, total withdrawals would be a ``small fraction'' of the river's flow and would nearly stop when the Athabasca was flowing at its lowest rate [1].


However, there is no research to suggest that the specific levels of withdrawals prescribed by the new water framework are compatible with the river ecosystem [1].
The framework is being heavily criticized for lack of scientific foundation [1].
Andy Ridge, director of water policy for Alberta Environment, acknowledges that the in-the-field science is scarce in the report. [1]
The framework relies on computer modelling to supplement the lack of empirical data. [1]
In 2011, Environment Canada and a team of independent experts concluded that the current water monitoring system for the Athabasca region “did not deliver data of sufficient quantity or quality to detect or quantify the effects of oilsands development.”[2]





 - Fish habitat, bug populations, water quality, groundwater, connections to tributaries -- none of those factors was considered. [1]
 - Even a couple inches in water levels can be critical, said Schindler. [1]
 - "The main fear about low flows is that it will leave eggs and embryos high and dry. It's like nobody wants to get out into the field and do some actual biology to see what flows the (plants and animals) require." [1]




 - We require industry to demonstrate that they are using the most appropriate source, namely that they’re going to the brackish or the saline groundwater before they use fresh groundwater and before they use fresh surface water,” Ridge says. [3]
 - This policy will put the onus on producers, particularly those involved in in-situ and hydraulic fracturing operations, to demonstrate that they have sourced, or exhausted all attempts to source, non-potable water and identified opportunities for water sharing and treatment before they are issued a license.





 - Adam's band has filed for a judicial review of a land-use plan for the area that includes the water-use framework.[1]







# In perspective #
- In CAPP’s 2013 Crude Oil Forecast, oil sands production is projected to rise to 5.2 million bpd in 2030 from 1.8 million bpd in 2012.[3]



# References #
[1] [CTV News, *Alberta's plan for Athabasca River 'pathetic,' not science-based: critics*](http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/alberta-s-plan-for-athabasca-river-pathetic-not-science-based-critics-1.1735778)
[2] [Pembina Institute, *Water Impacts*, 2013](http://www.pembina.org/oil-sands/os101/water#footnote3_iuh07fc
[3] [Alberta Oil, *Alberta desperately needs a water-management plan*, 2013](http://www.albertaoilmagazine.com/2013/07/alberta-and-the-life-aquatic/)

fields.title: Athebasca River water usage legislation
fields.text:
# Actors #
 - **Andy Ridge** -- Director of water policy for Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development.
 - **The Alberta Water Council** -- acts as an advisory board bringing stakeholders and experts together to oversee the implementation of water management strategies.
 - **Allan Adams** -- Chief of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation.  The Chipewyan First Nation uses the Athebasca river extensively, with three-quarters of their community on the river multiple times per week.
 - **Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers (CAPP)** -- an industry group representing the oilsands industry in Canada.
 - **Oil Sands Leadership Initiative (OSLI)** -- six oilsands companies that have initiated and advanced several improvements to water management practices.  Includes Suncor Energy Inc, ConocoPhillips Canada, Nexen Inc., Shell Canada Ltd., Statoil Canada and Total E+P Canada Ltd.


# Background #

In December 2014, the government of Alberta distributed a draft surface water quantity management framework for the Lower Athabasca River to industry, interest groups and First Nations [1].

Most of the water used for extraction of petroleum from the Albertan oilsands is taken from the Athabasca River [2].  In 2011, oilsands operators used about 170 million cubic metres of water, which is equivalent to the amount of water used by 1.7 million Canadians [2].  This demand is expected to grow five-fold by 2020 [1].

Surface water that is taken for oilsands extraction cannot be returned because of the toxins in the waste water.  Some water can be recycled within the extraction process, but ultimately, the water taken in ends up as waste water which has to be stored in tailings ponds or injected deep underground [2].

In Alberta’s north, water is abundant and demand is still ``relatively low''. But in the southern portion of the province, demand is straining the existing allocation regime and the ecology.   The southern basin is now closed to granting new surface water licenses [3].
Average discharge from lower Athebasca River's mouth into Lake Athabasca during low-flow periods was 30% less in 1996-2006 than it was in 1966-1976 [2].  Flow downstream of Fort McMurray is predicted to decrease by 30 per cent by 2050, due to the combined impacts of climate change and industrial water withdrawals [2].


Water withdrawals during winter low-flow periods risk reducing the availability of fish habitat [1]. Reduction of water flow can destroy the conditions needed for viability of and developing embryos of aquatic species in the river [1]. Even a couple inches in water levels can be critical, said Schindler. [1]

The Athebasca River is used extensively by about 1000 people from the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation.  According to Chief Allan Adam [1]:

    When we hit low water levels, a lot of our people won't even be able to get into their 
    traditional territory

About three-quarters of the Chipewyan people are on the river several times a week [1].
Adam's band has filed for a judicial review of a land-use plan for the area that includes the water-use framework [1].

In addition to affecting water levels, there is evidence that, despite the fact that water drawn from the river is not returned, industrial activity is nevertheless introducing harmful chemicals into the Athebasca River.
Independent research suggests concentrations of dissolved polycyclic aromatic compounds (PAC) are higher downstream of oilsands development, in comparison to upstream, in tributaries to the Athabasca [2]. 
This trend is more pronounced in the summer than in the winter [2].
Independent research has also found that sediment of lakes in the oilsands region (including one lake approximately 90 kilometres from the major development area) contain between 2.5 and 23 times higher concentrations of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) than they did 50 years ago, before the industrial development of the oilsands began [2].

The draft water management framework recently released by the government of Alberta would regulate how much water can be removed at different times of the year [1].
Its measures are expected to be implemented by fall 2015 [1].
At all times, total withdrawals would be a ``small fraction'' of the river's flow and would nearly stop when the Athabasca was flowing at its lowest rate [1].

However, there is no research to suggest that the specific levels of withdrawals prescribed by the new water framework are compatible with the river ecosystem [1].
The framework is being heavily criticized as lacking a scientific foundation [1].
The framework does not include studies of the impacts to fish, insects, and other organisms, nor effects on water quality [1].

Andy Ridge, director of water policy for Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development, acknowledges that empirical data is scarce in the drafted framework [1].
Instead, the framework relies on computer modelling to supplement the lack of empirical data [1].
This corroborates the 2011 findings of Environment Canada and a team of independent experts, who concluded that the current water monitoring system for the Athabasca region ``did not deliver data of sufficient quantity or quality to detect or quantify the effects of oilsands development.'' [2].

The existing water management policies require industrial operators to preferentially use brackish or saline groundwater, only turning to fresh groundwater when other sources do not suffice, and lastly to use fresh surface water [3].

# Impacts #
## Economic impacts ##
**Realistic and enforceable regulations.** Water usage regulations, as with any regulations, should be consistent with economic and technological constraints.  All other things being equal, more restrictive regulations lead to higher costs in petroleum extraction.  On the other hand, regulations can help create the impetus for technological innovation, which may lead to more efficient and cost-effective approaches in the long-run.

## Environmental impacts.##
**Ecological damage.** The use of water from the Athabasca river by oilsands operators may cause serious ecological damage.  The lack of scientific research on these effects means that the trade off between economic gains and ecological damages are unknown.  This condition of uncertainty it is likely to lead to greater ecological damage than would arise if the ecological damages were understood. 

## Social ##
**Disturbance to local people.** The Athebasca river is a source of livelihood for the Athabasca Chipewyan people.

## Health ##
**Concerns for the health of local people.** The observation of hydrocarbon chemicals raises serious concerns about the health effects for people relying on the Athebasca river, including the Athabasca Chipewyan people.

# In perspective #
- In CAPP’s 2013 Crude Oil Forecast, oil sands production is projected to rise to 5.2 million bpd in 2030 from 1.8 million bpd in 2012.[3]


# References #
[1] [CTV News, *Alberta's plan for Athabasca River 'pathetic,' not science-based: critics*](http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/alberta-s-plan-for-athabasca-river-pathetic-not-science-based-critics-1.1735778)
[2] [Pembina Institute, *Water Impacts*, 2013](http://www.pembina.org/oil-sands/os101/water#footnote3_iuh07fc
[3] [Alberta Oil, *Alberta desperately needs a water-management plan*, 2013](http://www.albertaoilmagazine.com/2013/07/alberta-and-the-life-aquatic/)

The Director of water policy for Albertan Environment and Sustainable Resource Development admits that there is little empirical data available upon which to base the framework.

Surface water that is taken for oilsands extraction cannot be returned because of the toxins in the waste water.  Some water can be recycled within the extraction process, but ultimately, the water taken in ends up as waste water which has to be stored in tailings ponds or injected deep underground [2].

In Alberta’s north, water is abundant and demand is still ``relatively low''. But in the southern portion of the province, demand is straining the existing allocation regime and the ecology.   The southern basin is now closed to granting new surface water licenses [3].
Average discharge from lower Athebasca River's mouth into Lake Athabasca during low-flow periods was 30% less in 1996-2006 than it was in 1966-1976 [2].  Flow downstream of Fort McMurray is predicted to decrease by 30 per cent by 2050, due to the combined impacts of climate change and industrial water withdrawals [2].


Water withdrawals during winter low-flow periods risk reducing the availability of fish habitat [1]. Reduction of water flow can destroy the conditions needed for viability of and developing embryos of aquatic species in the river [1]. Even a couple inches in water levels can be critical, said Schindler. [1]

The Athebasca River is used extensively by about 1000 people from the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation.  According to Chief Allan Adam [1]:

    When we hit low water levels, a lot of our people won't even be able to 
    get into their traditional territory.

About three-quarters of the Chipewyan people are on the river several times a week [1].
Adam's band has filed for a judicial review of a land-use plan for the area that includes the water-use framework [1].

In addition to affecting water levels, there is evidence that, despite the fact that water drawn from the river is not returned, industrial activity is nevertheless introducing harmful chemicals into the Athebasca River.
Independent research suggests concentrations of dissolved polycyclic aromatic compounds (PAC) are higher downstream of oilsands development, in comparison to upstream, in tributaries to the Athabasca [2]. 
This trend is more pronounced in the summer than in the winter [2].
Independent research has also found that sediment of lakes in the oilsands region (including one lake approximately 90 kilometres from the major development area) contain between 2.5 and 23 times higher concentrations of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) than they did 50 years ago, before the industrial development of the oilsands began [2].

The draft water management framework recently released by the government of Alberta would regulate how much water can be removed at different times of the year [1].
Its measures are expected to be implemented by fall 2015 [1].
At all times, total withdrawals would be a ``small fraction'' of the river's flow and would nearly stop when the Athabasca was flowing at its lowest rate [1].

However, there is no research to suggest that the specific levels of withdrawals prescribed by the new water framework are compatible with the river ecosystem [1].
The framework is being heavily criticized as lacking a scientific foundation [1].
The framework does not include studies of the impacts to fish, insects, and other organisms, nor effects on water quality [1].

Andy Ridge, director of water policy for Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development, acknowledges that empirical data is scarce in the drafted framework [1].
Instead, the framework relies on computer modelling to supplement the lack of empirical data [1].
This corroborates the 2011 findings of Environment Canada and a team of independent experts, who concluded that the current water monitoring system for the Athabasca region ``did not deliver data of sufficient quantity or quality to detect or quantify the effects of oilsands development.'' [2].

The existing water management policies require industrial operators to preferentially use brackish or saline groundwater, only turning to fresh groundwater when other sources do not suffice, and lastly to use fresh surface water [3].

# Impacts #
## Economic impacts ##
**Realistic and enforceable regulations.** Water usage regulations, as with any regulations, should be consistent with economic and technological constraints.  All other things being equal, more restrictive regulations lead to higher costs in petroleum extraction.  On the other hand, regulations can help create the impetus for technological innovation, which may lead to more efficient and cost-effective approaches in the long-run.

## Environmental impacts.##
**Ecological damage.** The use of water from the Athabasca river by oilsands operators may cause serious ecological damage.  The lack of scientific research on these effects means that the trade off between economic gains and ecological damages are unknown.  This condition of uncertainty it is likely to lead to greater ecological damage than would arise if the ecological damages were understood. 

## Social ##
**Disturbance to local people.** The Athebasca river is a source of livelihood for the Athabasca Chipewyan people.

## Health ##
**Concerns for the health of local people.** The observation of hydrocarbon chemicals raises serious concerns about the health effects for people relying on the Athebasca river, including the Athabasca Chipewyan people.

# In perspective #
- In CAPP’s 2013 Crude Oil Forecast, oil sands production is projected to rise to 5.2 million bpd in 2030 from 1.8 million bpd in 2012.[3]


# References #
[1] [CTV News, *Alberta's plan for Athabasca River 'pathetic,' not science-based: critics*](http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/alberta-s-plan-for-athabasca-river-pathetic-not-science-based-critics-1.1735778)  
[2] [Pembina Institute, *Water Impacts*, 2013](http://www.pembina.org/oil-sands/os101/water#footnote3_iuh07fc)  
[3] [Alberta Oil, *Alberta desperately needs a water-management plan*, 2013](http://www.albertaoilmagazine.com/2013/07/alberta-and-the-life-aquatic/)

fields.title: Doubling TFSA contribution limits
fields.text:
#Background#
The TFSA account was first introduced in 2009 to encourage Canadians to save. Originally the account allowed for contributions of up to $5,000 per year. 

# Actors #
 - **Government**: The Government wants to provide incentive for Canadians to save money. At the same time it has to balance the budget and ensure that no group of Canadians are unfairly benefiting from the regulations. 
 - **Banks**: Banks benefit by holding TFSA deposits because the rules of this account discourage Canadians from withdrawing money on a regular basis. When money is withdrawn from a TFSA account, the contribution room is not freed up until the following year. By having longer-term accounts banks can invest the funds in lucrative mortgages or credit card offers, while giving only a negligible portion of the earnings as interest back to the TFSA account holder.
 - **Average Canadians**: The average working class Canadian benefits from TFSA accounts by means of tax-free interest and incentive to keep healthy financial discipline.
 - **Savvy investors and traders**: Savvy investors and traders are able to exploit the full potential of a TFSA. The TFSA is a very flexible investment vehicle, particularly if used as a self-directed account. It can hold a large variety of securities and financial instruments, similar to a RRSP account. The few exclusions relate to shares in companies of which the TFSA account holder has controlling role. Savvy individuals with access to highly lucrative investments have a virtually unlimited potential to earn tax-free income by re-investing earnings within the TFSA account.

# Impacts #
## Unfair advantages ##
**Tax avoidance**. When the TFSA was first introduced, savvy investors and traders took unfair advantage of the weak penalties for over-contribution and unqualified investments. The original penalty for over contribution was only 1% per month (and only on the over-contributions). Wealthy investors with access to investments with high returns were over-contributing $100,000 or more, paying the 1% penalty and still keeping all returns as tax-free income. Furthermore, initially the penalty for purchasing prohibited investments inside a TFSA (such as the shares of a company you control) was simply forfeiting the purchase. I.e., investors with questionable morality were allowed to keep any capital gains from breaking the rules, without paying tax[1].
While the rules have since changed to prevent the most obvious tax avoidance schemes, questions still remain about what other opportunities for abuse are being exploited.

**Unequal opportunities**. In 2010 big banks held 75% of Tax-Free Savings Accounts[2]. That is to say, 75% of accounts were giving their owners only the marginal interest rate that the big banks offer. At the same time, the remaining 25% of TFSAs were self-directed or held by other institutions, offering lucrative investments with limitless tax exemption to those in the know. Fast-forward to 2012, less than 16% of TFSA account holders under 60 years old had reached the $5,500 contribution limit[3]. I.e., only 16% of the economically active Canadian residents with TFSA accounts have enough spare income to reach the $5,500 TFSA contribution limit. If the limit is doubled, then, fewer than 16% of working Canadians will be able to benefit from this tax-break.

## Economic Impacts ##
**Loss of tax income**. By having no limits on the types of investments in a TFSA, the government in power leaves an unpredictable tax loss for future governments. The amount of tax wealthy investors and knowledgeable traders will not pay into future budgets depends only on their luck and skills. Doubling the contribution limit has cumulative impact on the tax loss, as any earnings can be re-invested freely.

**Reduced economic activity**. Encouraging Canadians to invest up to $11,000 of their yearly income in a savings account and penalizing them (by means of lost contribution room) for withdrawals, may negatively impact local businesses as less money will be circulating in the economy. This will put deflationary pressure on an economy that is already struggling to achieve inflation targets.

**Cushion for rate hike**. The TFSA can have a positive impact on the economy by providing a cushion for future changes that may take households by surprise. For instance, the abnormally low interest rate has allowed a large number of people to take mortgages. If the interest rates recover, a TFSA could save home-owners who are facing unexpected increase in the payments for their home.

# References #
[1] [The Globe and Mail, *TFSA move targets savvy investors*, 2009](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/personal-finance/tfsa-move-targets-savvy-investors/article4215495/)  
[2] [The Globe and Mail, *Taxman may forgive TFSA rule breakers*, 2010](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/personal-finance/taxman-may-forgive-tfsa-rule-breakers/article1373287/)  
[3] [CBC, *Doubling TFSA limit will only help wealthy, study argues*, 2015](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/doubling-tfsa-limit-will-only-help-wealthy-study-argues-1.2967796)
fields.summary:
The Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) is a special type of account which allows Canadian residents to contribute after-tax funds up to a yearly contribution limit. Any earnings within the TFSA account (such as interest or capital gains) are tax-free. The individual can choose to withdraw funds from his/her TFSA at any time without being subject to tax on the withdrawals.
The Conservative government has proposed to dobule the TFSA contribution limit from the current $5,500 per year to $11,000 per year.

Furthermore, initially the penalty for purchasing prohibited investments inside a TFSA (such as the shares of a company you control) was simply forfeiting the purchase. This means that investors with questionable morality were allowed to keep any capital gains resulting from prohibited investments, without paying tax[1].
While the rules have since changed to prevent the most obvious tax avoidance schemes, questions still remain about what other opportunities for abuse are being exploited.

**Unequal opportunities**. In 2010 big banks held 75% of Tax-Free Savings Accounts[2]. That is to say, 75% of accounts were giving their owners only the marginal interest rate that the big banks offer. At the same time, the remaining 25% of TFSAs were self-directed or held by other institutions, offering lucrative investments with limitless tax exemption to those in the know. In 2012, less than 16% of TFSA account holders under 60 years old had reached the $5,500 contribution limit[3]. I.e., only 16% of the economically active Canadian residents with TFSA accounts have enough spare income to reach the $5,500 TFSA contribution limit. If the limit is doubled, then, fewer than 16% of working Canadians will be able to benefit from this tax-break.

## Economic Impacts ##
**Loss of tax income**. By having no limits on the types of investments in a TFSA, the government in power leaves an unpredictable tax loss for future governments. The amount of tax wealthy investors and knowledgeable traders will not pay into future budgets depends only on their luck and skills. Doubling the contribution limit has cumulative impact on the tax loss, as any earnings can be re-invested freely.

**Reduced economic activity**. Encouraging Canadians to invest up to $11,000 of their yearly income in a savings account and penalizing them (by means of lost contribution room) for withdrawals, may negatively impact local businesses as less money will be circulating in the economy. This will put deflationary pressure on an economy that is already struggling to achieve inflation targets.

**Cushion for rate hike**. The TFSA can have a positive impact on the economy by providing a cushion for future changes that may take households by surprise. For instance, the abnormally low interest rate has allowed a large number of people to take mortgages. If the interest rates recover, a TFSA could save home-owners who are facing unexpected increase in the payments for their home.

# References #
[1] [The Globe and Mail, *TFSA move targets savvy investors*, 2009](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/personal-finance/tfsa-move-targets-savvy-investors/article4215495/)  
[2] [The Globe and Mail, *Taxman may forgive TFSA rule breakers*, 2010](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/personal-finance/taxman-may-forgive-tfsa-rule-breakers/article1373287/)  
[3] [CBC, *Doubling TFSA limit will only help wealthy, study argues*, 2015](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/doubling-tfsa-limit-will-only-help-wealthy-study-argues-1.2967796)
fields.summary: The Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) allows Canadian residents to contribute after-tax funds up to a yearly contribution limit. Funds in a TFSA account can be invested, for example, in stocks, and any interest or capital gains are tax-free. The individual can choose to withdraw funds from his/her TFSA at any time without being subject to tax on the withdrawals. The Conservative government has proposed to double the TFSA contribution limit from the current $5,500 per year to $11,000 per year.  TFSA accounts create great opportunities for savvy investers, while the benefit ordinary Canadians are comparatively modest.

fields.title: Athabasca River water usage legislation
fields.text:
# Actors #
 - **Andy Ridge** -- Director of water policy for Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development.
 - **The Alberta Water Council** -- acts as an advisory board bringing stakeholders and experts together to oversee the implementation of water management strategies.
 - **Allan Adams** -- Chief of the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation.  The Chipewyan First Nation uses the Athabasca river extensively, with three-quarters of their community on the river multiple times per week.
 - **Canadian Association of Petroleum Producers (CAPP)** -- an industry group representing the oilsands industry in Canada.
 - **Oil Sands Leadership Initiative (OSLI)** -- six oilsands companies that have initiated and advanced several improvements to water management practices.  Includes Suncor Energy Inc, ConocoPhillips Canada, Nexen Inc., Shell Canada Ltd., Statoil Canada and Total E+P Canada Ltd.


# Background #

In December 2014, the government of Alberta distributed a draft surface water quantity management framework for the Lower Athabasca River to industry, interest groups and First Nations [1].

Most of the water used for extraction of petroleum from the Albertan oilsands is taken from the Athabasca River [2].  In 2011, oilsands operators used about 170 million cubic metres of water, which is equivalent to the amount of water used by 1.7 million Canadians [2].  This demand is expected to grow five-fold by 2020 [1].

Surface water that is taken for oilsands extraction cannot be returned because of the toxins in the waste water.  Some water can be recycled within the extraction process, but ultimately, the water taken in ends up as waste water which has to be stored in tailings ponds or injected deep underground [2].

In Alberta’s north, water is abundant and demand is still ``relatively low''. But in the southern portion of the province, demand is straining the existing allocation regime and the ecology.   The southern basin is now closed to granting new surface water licenses [3].
Average discharge from lower Athabasca River's mouth into Lake Athabasca during low-flow periods was 30% less in 1996-2006 than it was in 1966-1976 [2].  Flow downstream of Fort McMurray is predicted to decrease by 30 per cent by 2050, due to the combined impacts of climate change and industrial water withdrawals [2].


Water withdrawals during winter low-flow periods risk reducing the availability of fish habitat [1]. Reduction of water flow can destroy the conditions needed for viability of and developing embryos of aquatic species in the river [1]. Even a couple inches in water levels can be critical, said Schindler. [1]

The Athabasca River is used extensively by about 1000 people from the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation.  According to Chief Allan Adam [1]: "When we hit low water levels, a lot of our people won't even be able to get into their traditional territory.".

About three-quarters of the Chipewyan people are on the river several times a week [1].
Adam's band has filed for a judicial review of a land-use plan for the area that includes the water-use framework [1].

In addition to affecting water levels, there is evidence that, despite the fact that water drawn from the river is not returned, industrial activity is nevertheless introducing harmful chemicals into the Athabasca River.
Independent research suggests concentrations of dissolved polycyclic aromatic compounds (PAC) are higher downstream of oilsands development, in comparison to upstream, in tributaries to the Athabasca [2]. 
This trend is more pronounced in the summer than in the winter [2].
Independent research has also found that sediment of lakes in the oilsands region (including one lake approximately 90 kilometres from the major development area) contain between 2.5 and 23 times higher concentrations of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) than they did 50 years ago, before the industrial development of the oilsands began [2].

The draft water management framework recently released by the government of Alberta would regulate how much water can be removed at different times of the year [1].
Its measures are expected to be implemented by fall 2015 [1].
At all times, total withdrawals would be a ``small fraction'' of the river's flow and would nearly stop when the Athabasca was flowing at its lowest rate [1].

However, there is no research to suggest that the specific levels of withdrawals prescribed by the new water framework are compatible with the river ecosystem [1].
The framework is being heavily criticized as lacking a scientific foundation [1].
The framework does not include studies of the impacts to fish, insects, and other organisms, nor effects on water quality [1].

Andy Ridge, director of water policy for Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development, acknowledges that empirical data is scarce in the drafted framework [1].
Instead, the framework relies on computer modelling to supplement the lack of empirical data [1].
This corroborates the 2011 findings of Environment Canada and a team of independent experts, who concluded that the current water monitoring system for the Athabasca region ``did not deliver data of sufficient quantity or quality to detect or quantify the effects of oilsands development.'' [2].

The existing water management policies require industrial operators to preferentially use brackish or saline groundwater, only turning to fresh groundwater when other sources do not suffice, and lastly to use fresh surface water [3].

# Impacts #
## Economic impacts ##
**Realistic and enforceable regulations.** Water usage regulations, as with any regulations, should be consistent with economic and technological constraints.  All other things being equal, more restrictive regulations lead to higher costs in petroleum extraction.  On the other hand, regulations can help create the impetus for technological innovation, which may lead to more efficient and cost-effective approaches in the long-run.

## Environmental impacts.##
**Ecological damage.** The use of water from the Athabasca river by oilsands operators may cause serious ecological damage.  The lack of scientific research on these effects means that the trade off between economic gains and ecological damages are unknown.  This condition of uncertainty it is likely to lead to greater ecological damage than would arise if the ecological damages were understood. 

## Social ##
**Disturbance to local people.** The Athabasca river is a source of livelihood for the Athabasca Chipewyan people.

## Health ##
**Concerns for the health of local people.** The observation of hydrocarbon chemicals raises serious concerns about the health effects for people relying on the Athabasca river, including the Athabasca Chipewyan people.

# In perspective #
- In CAPP’s 2013 Crude Oil Forecast, oil sands production is projected to rise to 5.2 million bpd in 2030 from 1.8 million bpd in 2012.[3]


# References #
[1] [CTV News, *Alberta's plan for Athabasca River 'pathetic,' not science-based: critics*](http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/alberta-s-plan-for-athabasca-river-pathetic-not-science-based-critics-1.1735778)  
[2] [Pembina Institute, *Water Impacts*, 2013](http://www.pembina.org/oil-sands/os101/water#footnote3_iuh07fc)  
[3] [Alberta Oil, *Alberta desperately needs a water-management plan*, 2013](http://www.albertaoilmagazine.com/2013/07/alberta-and-the-life-aquatic/)
fields.summary: Scientists criticize the Alberta's water management framework drafted in December 2014 for having little scientific basis.  The Director of water policy for Albertan Environment and Sustainable Resource Development admits that there is little empirical data available upon which to base the framework.

Its measures are expected to be implemented by fall 2015 [1].
At all times, total withdrawals would be a "small fraction" of the river's flow and would nearly stop when the Athabasca was flowing at its lowest rate [1].

However, there is no research to suggest that the specific levels of withdrawals prescribed by the new water framework are compatible with the river ecosystem [1].
The framework is being heavily criticized as lacking a scientific foundation [1].
The framework does not include studies of the impacts to fish, insects, and other organisms, nor effects on water quality [1].

Andy Ridge, director of water policy for Alberta Environment and Sustainable Resource Development, acknowledges that empirical data is scarce in the drafted framework [1].
Instead, the framework relies on computer modeling to supplement the lack of empirical data [1].
This corroborates the 2011 findings of Environment Canada and a team of independent experts, who concluded that the current water monitoring system for the Athabasca region "did not deliver data of sufficient quantity or quality to detect or quantify the effects of oilsands development." [2].

The existing water management policies do require industrial operators to preferentially use brackish or saline groundwater, only turning to fresh groundwater when other sources do not suffice, and lastly to use fresh surface water [3].

# Impacts #
## Economic impacts ##
**Realistic and enforceable regulations.** Water usage regulations, as with any regulations, should be consistent with economic and technological constraints.  All other things being equal, more restrictive regulations lead to higher costs in petroleum extraction.  On the other hand, regulations can help create the impetus for technological innovation, which may lead to more efficient and cost-effective approaches in the long-run.

## Environmental impacts.##
**Ecological damage.** The use of water from the Athabasca river by oilsands operators may cause serious ecological damage.  The lack of scientific research on these effects means that the trade off between economic gains and ecological damages are unknown.  This condition of uncertainty it is likely to lead to greater ecological damages, since they are going unmonitored. 

## Social ##
**Disturbance to local people.** The Athabasca river is a source of livelihood for the Athabasca Chipewyan people.

## Health ##
**Concerns for the health of local people.** The observation of hydrocarbons raises serious concerns about the health effects for people relying on the Athabasca River, including the Athabasca Chipewyan people.

# In perspective #
- In CAPP’s 2013 Crude Oil Forecast, oil sands production is projected to rise to 5.2 million bpd in 2030 from 1.8 million bpd in 2012.[3]


# References #
[1] [CTV News, *Alberta's plan for Athabasca River 'pathetic,' not science-based: critics*](http://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/alberta-s-plan-for-athabasca-river-pathetic-not-science-based-critics-1.1735778)  
[2] [Pembina Institute, *Water Impacts*, 2013](http://www.pembina.org/oil-sands/os101/water#footnote3_iuh07fc)  
[3] [Alberta Oil, *Alberta desperately needs a water-management plan*, 2013](http://www.albertaoilmagazine.com/2013/07/alberta-and-the-life-aquatic/)
fields.summary: Scientists have criticized Alberta's new water management framework, drafted in December 2014, as having little scientific basis.  The Director of water policy for Albertan Environment and Sustainable Resource Development admits that there is little empirical data available upon which to base the framework.  Intensive use of water from the Athabaska river, mainly by oilsands operations, is threatening to eliminate habitats, but the actual impacts are unknown due to lack of field research.

fields.title: Canada's involvement in Syria and Iraq
fields.text:
# Background #

## Origins of ISIS ##
ISIS, the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, also goes by the names ISIL, the Islamic State of Syria and the Levant, and simply IS, Islamic State.  ISIS is a jihadist group that grew in the wake of the Iraq war.  After the US and UK overthrew the oppressive autocrat Saddam Hussein, regional, ethnic, and religious conflicts came to the fore [6].  Furthermore, the militias that the US had armed and allied with to defeat Saddam Hussein were themselves 

It originally spun off from Al-Qaeda.  Seeking to create an Islamic state in Iraq, instability within Syria has created an opportunity for it take territory there.  Currently it occupies a large territory straddling the border between Iraq and Syria [3].  ISIS seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Koran. [3]

## Conflict in Syria ##
The Syrian Government is headed by president Bashar Al-Assad.  Assad is an oppressive autocrat who has repeatedly used the Syrian army to kill dissenters and protesters.  Under Assad's leadership, the government has bombed its own people, and is alleged to have used chemical weapons on them as well.

The oppressive reign of Assad has led to the emergence of rebel groups that seek to overthrow and replace the government.  The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between them [10].  Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad and ISIS are almost as brutal: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Meanwhile, the crimes against humanity committed by Assad's regime arguably surpass even ISIS itself [10].

## Canada's involvement in Syria ##


## Actors ##
*[Note these are the decision makers relative to Canada's involvement, not the many players in the complex situation in Syria.  I.e. PM, leader of opposition, etc, other influencers such as advisors]*

## Impacts ##
### Relations ###
*[How will our involvement contribute to relations to our allies?]*
*[How does this affect our image abroad?]*

### Impacts in Syria ###
*[How will our involvement contribute to the situation in Syria.  What improvements could occur, as well as what unintended consequences may arise]*

### Social ###
*[Is it a good idea to be sending our young people over there?  What situation are they likely to meet.  Is the potential benefit worth it?]*
*[What can be said about our obligations to intervene?]*

fields.title: Canada's involvement in Syria and Iraq
fields.text:
# Background #

## Origins of ISIS ##
ISIS, the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, also goes by the names ISIL, the Islamic State of Syria and the Levant, and simply IS, Islamic State.  ISIS is a jihadist group that grew in the wake of the Iraq war.  After the US and UK overthrew the oppressive autocrat Saddam Hussein, regional, ethnic, and religious conflicts came to the fore [6].  Furthermore, the militias that the US had armed and allied with to defeat Saddam Hussein were themselves brutal warlards, who, after the defeat of Saddam Hussein, turned on one another and the US.

ISIS is a splinter group of Al-Qaeda.  Seeking to create an Islamic state in Iraq, instability within Syria has created an opportunity for it take territory there.  Currently it occupies a large territory straddling the border between Iraq and Syria [3].  ISIS seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Koran. [3]

## Conflict in Syria ##
The Syrian Government is headed by president Bashar Al-Assad.  Assad is an oppressive autocrat who has repeatedly used the Syrian army to kill dissenters and protesters.  Under Assad's leadership, the government has bombed its own people, and is alleged to have used chemical weapons on them as well.

The oppressive reign of Assad has led to the emergence of rebel groups that seek to overthrow and replace the government.  The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between them [10].  Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad and ISIS are almost as brutal: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Meanwhile, the crimes against humanity committed by Assad's regime arguably surpass even ISIS itself [10].

## Canada's initial involvement in Syria ##
**Decision.** In October 2015, after assent by the house of Commons, the government approved the Canadian forces participation in a coalition effort to fight ISIS.  The coalition is US-led, and includes the UK, France, Australia, and many Arab countries [3].  More than 60 countries have joined the coalition [2].  

**Operations.** The coalition operates under the following limits [3]:
 - no ground fighting
 - use airstrikes to attack ISIS positions and disrupt supply lines

However, Canada's Joint Task Force 2, the elite special forces, were involved in training Kurdish soldiers in combat zones[3].  Only the US and its Arab allies have been active in Syria, Canada, and the other western members of the Coalition, have been active only in Iraq [3].

Canada's contribution to the effort consists of 600 soldiers, 6 CF-18s (plus one spare), two Aurora reconnaissance planes, and a Polaris aerial refueller [3].  Since 2 Nov, Canadian forces have flown CF-18s daily in a state of readiness to attack [3; 8].  Within the first two weeks of air operations, Canadian war planes destroyed 2 ISIS targets [1].  

Canadian forces operate under a strict no-civilian casualty policy, and will not strike a target unless the risk of civilian casualties is zero.

**Cost.** The first six months of deployment cost CAD$ 122 M.

**Effects.** As of Nov 02 2014, after three months of airstrikes by coalition forces, ISIS appeared undeterred [3].  ISIS Targets have become more difficult to find because they are increasingly hiding among civilian populations, where they are impossible to target without casualties [3].  ISIS has also increasingly shifted its forces to it's western front in Syria, which is outside of Canada's mandate, and that of the other Western allies except the US.  Shortly after Canada joined the effort, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on all
inti-ISIS coalition forces, and specifically named Canada [2].

## Proposed extension of Canada's mandate ##
**Time extension.** Canada's participation in the fight against ISIS would be extended for one year, until March 2016.

**Geographical extension.** The government proposes to extend Canada's mandate to include airstrikes in Syria. 

## Actors ##
*[Note these are the decision makers relative to Canada's involvement, not the many players in the complex situation in Syria.  I.e. PM, leader of opposition, etc, other influencers such as advisors]*

## Impacts ##
### Relations ###
*[How will our involvement contribute to relations to our allies?]*
*[How does this affect our image abroad?]*

### Impacts in Syria ###
*[How will our involvement contribute to the situation in Syria.  What improvements could occur, as well as what unintended consequences may arise]*

### Social ###
*[Is it a good idea to be sending our young people over there?  What situation are they likely to meet.  Is the potential benefit worth it?]*
*[What can be said about our obligations to intervene?]*

fields.title: Canada's involvement in Syria and Iraq
fields.text:
# Background #

## ISIS ##
**Origins.** ISIS, the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, also goes by the names ISIL, the Islamic State of Syria and the Levant, and simply IS, Islamic State.  ISIS is a jihadist group that grew in the wake of the Iraq war.  After the US and UK overthrew the oppressive autocrat Saddam Hussein, regional, ethnic, and religious conflicts came to the fore [6].  Furthermore, the militias that the US had armed and allied with to defeat Saddam Hussein were themselves brutal warlards, who, after the defeat of Saddam Hussein, turned on one another and the US.

ISIS is a splinter group of Al-Qaeda.  Seeking to create an Islamic state in Iraq, instability within Syria has created an opportunity for it take territory there.  Currently it occupies a large territory straddling the border between Iraq and Syria [3].  ISIS seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Koran. [3]

**Identity.** ISIS proclaims that it represents Muslims of the world.  Despite their self-identification, they are shunned by the vast majority of muslims.  Nevertheless, adopting this posture, they proclaim that their enemies have declared war on Islam.  Their identification with Islam is the basis for their legitimacy internally and is used to recruit and radicalize new members. 

## Conflict in Syria ##
The Syrian Government is headed by president Bashar Al-Assad.  Assad is an oppressive autocrat who has repeatedly used the Syrian army to kill dissenters and protesters.  Under Assad's leadership, the government has bombed its own people, and is alleged to have used chemical weapons on them as well.

The oppressive reign of Assad has led to the emergence of rebel groups that seek to overthrow and replace the government.  The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between them [10].  Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad and ISIS are almost as brutal: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Meanwhile, the crimes against humanity committed by Assad's regime arguably surpass even ISIS itself [10].

The Syrian war has cost tens of thousands of lives [2].

## Canada's initial involvement in Syria ##
**Decision.** In October 2015, after assent by the house of Commons, the government approved the Canadian forces participation in a coalition effort to fight ISIS.  The coalition is US-led, and includes the UK, France, Australia, and many Arab countries [3].  More than 60 countries have joined the coalition [2].  

**Operations.** The coalition operates under the following limits [3]:

 - no ground fighting
 - use airstrikes to attack ISIS positions and disrupt supply lines

However, Canada's Joint Task Force 2, the elite special forces, were involved in training Kurdish soldiers in combat zones[3].  Only the US and its Arab allies have been active in Syria, Canada, and the other western members of the Coalition, have been active only in Iraq [3].

Canada's contribution to the effort consists of 600 soldiers, 6 CF-18s (plus one spare), two Aurora reconnaissance planes, and a Polaris aerial refueller [3].  Since 2 Nov, Canadian forces have flown CF-18s daily in a state of readiness to attack [3; 8].  Within the first two weeks of air operations, Canadian war planes destroyed 2 ISIS targets [1].  

Canadian forces operate under a strict no-civilian casualty policy, and will not strike a target unless the risk of civilian casualties is zero.

**Cost.** The first six months of deployment cost CAD$ 122 M.

**Effects.** As of Nov 02 2014, after three months of airstrikes by coalition forces, ISIS appeared undeterred [3].  ISIS Targets have become more difficult to find because they are increasingly hiding among civilian populations, where they are impossible to target without casualties [3].  ISIS has also increasingly shifted its forces to it's western front in Syria, which is outside of Canada's mandate, and that of the other Western allies except the US.  Shortly after Canada joined the effort, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on all
inti-ISIS coalition forces, and specifically named Canada [2].

## Proposed extension of Canada's mandate ##
**Time extension.** Canada's participation in the fight against ISIS would be extended for one year, until March 2016.

**Geographical extension.** The government proposes to extend Canada's mandate to include airstrikes in Syria. 



## The case for intervention ##
Some people argue that earlier intervention in Iraq and Syria could have avoided such a decline to chaos that enabled ISIS to flourish [2]. 

# Actors #
*[Note these are the decision makers relative to Canada's involvement, not the many players in the complex situation in Syria.  I.e. PM, leader of opposition, etc, other influencers such as advisors]*

# Impacts #
## Relations ##
There is a sense of responsibility to join with our allies in fighting ISIS.  Although there is no clear path toward stability in the Syria-Iraq region, ISIS is universally seen as the most violent and menacing group, and there is a general sense that ISIS must be resisted by countries who have the means.  Failing to engage would probably be seen by our allies as a fairly serious omission and a neglect of our moral duty.

## Impacts in Syria ##
While the expansion of ISIS surely leads to enormous atrocity, there is no clear path to stability in these areas.  The other groups in the region, who vie for power, are almost equally brutal and fighting ISIS tacitly supports these groups.  If ISIS is significantly degraded, it is not clear that people in Syria and Iraq will be any better off, since they face similar treatment by other groups. 

## Social ##
*[Is it a good idea to be sending our young people over there?  What situation are they likely to meet.  Is the potential benefit worth it?]*
*[What can be said about our obligations to intervene?]*
