Canadian forces operate under a strict no-civilian casualty policy, and will not strike a target unless the risk of civilian casualties is zero.

**Cost.** The first six months of deployment cost CAD$ 122 M.

**Effects.** As of Nov 02 2014, after three months of airstrikes by coalition forces, ISIS appeared undeterred [3].  ISIS Targets have become more difficult to find because they are increasingly hiding among civilian populations, where they are impossible to target without casualties [3].  ISIS has also increasingly shifted its forces to it's western front in Syria, which is outside of Canada's mandate, and that of the other Western allies except the US.  Shortly after Canada joined the effort, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on all
inti-ISIS coalition forces, and specifically named Canada [2].

## Proposed extension of Canada's mandate ##
**Time extension.** Canada's participation in the fight against ISIS would be extended for one year, until March 2016.

**Geographical extension.** The government proposes to extend Canada's mandate to include airstrikes in Syria. 



## The case for intervention ##
Some people argue that earlier intervention in Iraq and Syria could have avoided such a decline to chaos that enabled ISIS to flourish [2]. 

# Actors #
*[Note these are the decision makers relative to Canada's involvement, not the many players in the complex situation in Syria.  I.e. PM, leader of opposition, etc, other influencers such as advisors]*

# Impacts #
## Relations ##
There is a sense of responsibility to join with our allies in fighting ISIS.  Although there is no clear path toward stability in the Syria-Iraq region, ISIS is universally seen as the most violent and menacing group, and there is a general sense that ISIS must be resisted by countries who have the means.  Failing to engage would probably be seen by our allies as a fairly serious omission and a neglect of our moral duty.

## Impacts in Syria ##
While the expansion of ISIS surely leads to enormous atrocity, there is no clear path to stability in these areas.  The other groups in the region, who vie for power, are almost equally brutal and fighting ISIS tacitly supports these groups.  If ISIS is significantly degraded, it is not clear that people in Syria and Iraq will be any better off, since they face similar treatment by other groups.

## Readiness ##
**Security.** Intervening in this conflict may not be likely to bring it any closer to solution, but it does create new enemies.  By fighting ISIS, we make Canada a target for acts of terrorism.

## Economic ##
Canada's resources, especially militarily, are limited.  A recent report by the Parliamentary Budget Office, finds that the current defense program cannot be sustained without increasing the military budget.  It is not clear that the investment we make in fighting ISIS will have an impact, which questions whether this spending is justified.
fields.summary:
Since October 2014, Canada has been helping allies fight ISIS (the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria), by engaging in airstrikes over Iraq.  Now the government is planning to extend this involvement (originally approved for six months), for an additional year, while expanding its engagement to Syria.

ISIS is an extremely violent, jihadist group, which identifies itself as Sunni Muslim, and seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Koran.

fields.title: Canada's involvement in Syria and Iraq
fields.text:
# Background #

## ISIS ##
**Origins.** ISIS, the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, also goes by the names ISIL, the Islamic State of Syria and the Levant, and simply IS, Islamic State.  ISIS is a jihadist group that grew in the wake of the Iraq war.  After the US and UK overthrew the oppressive autocrat Saddam Hussein, regional, ethnic, and religious conflicts came to the fore [6].  Furthermore, the militias that the US had armed and allied with to defeat Saddam Hussein were themselves brutal warlords, who, after the defeat of Saddam Hussein, turned on one another and the US.

ISIS is a splinter group of Al-Qaeda.  Seeking to create an Islamic state in Iraq, instability within Syria has created an opportunity for it take territory there.  Currently it occupies a large territory straddling the border between Iraq and Syria [3].  ISIS seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Quran. [3]

**Identity.** ISIS proclaims that it represents Muslims of the world.  Despite their self-identification, they are shunned by the vast majority of Muslims.  Nevertheless, adopting this posture, they proclaim that their enemies have declared war on Islam.  Their identification with Islam is the basis for their legitimacy internally and is used to recruit and radicalize new members. 

## Conflict in Syria ##
The Syrian Government is headed by president Bashar Al-Assad.  Assad is an oppressive autocrat who has repeatedly used the Syrian army to kill dissenters and protesters.  Under Assad's leadership, the government has bombed its own people, and is alleged to have used chemical weapons on them as well.

The oppressive reign of Assad has led to the emergence of rebel groups that seek to overthrow and replace the government.  The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between them [10].  Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad and ISIS are almost as brutal: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Meanwhile, the crimes against humanity committed by Assad's regime arguably surpass even ISIS itself [10].

The Syrian war has cost tens of thousands of lives [2].

## Canada's initial involvement in Syria ##
**Decision.** In October 2015, after assent by the house of Commons, the government approved the Canadian forces participation in a coalition effort to fight ISIS.  The coalition is US-led, and includes the UK, France, Australia, and many Arab countries [3].  More than 60 countries have joined the coalition [2].  

**Operations.** The coalition operates under the following limits [3]:

 - no ground fighting
 - use airstrikes to attack ISIS positions and disrupt supply lines

However, Canada's Joint Task Force 2, the elite special forces, were involved in training Kurdish soldiers in combat zones[3].  Only the US and its Arab allies have been active in Syria, Canada, and the other western members of the Coalition, have been active only in Iraq [3].

Canada's contribution to the effort consists of 600 soldiers, 6 CF-18s (plus one spare), two Aurora reconnaissance planes, and a Polaris aerial refueller [3].  Since 2 Nov, Canadian forces have flown CF-18s daily in a state of readiness to attack [3; 8].  Within the first two weeks of air operations, Canadian war planes destroyed 2 ISIS targets [1].  

Canadian forces operate under a strict no-civilian casualty policy, and will not strike a target unless the risk of civilian casualties is zero.

**Cost.** The first six months of deployment cost CAD$ 122 M.

**Effects.** As of Nov 02 2014, after three months of airstrikes by coalition forces, ISIS appeared undeterred [3].  ISIS Targets have become more difficult to find because they are increasingly hiding among civilian populations, where they are impossible to target without casualties [3].  ISIS has also increasingly shifted its forces to it's western front in Syria, which is outside of Canada's mandate, and that of the other Western allies except the US.  Shortly after Canada joined the effort, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on all
anti-ISIS coalition forces, and specifically named Canada [2].

## Proposed extension of Canada's mandate ##
**Time extension.** Canada's participation in the fight against ISIS would be extended for one year, until March 2016.

**Geographical extension.** The government proposes to extend Canada's mandate to include airstrikes in Syria. 



## The case for intervention ##
Some people argue that earlier intervention in Iraq and Syria could have avoided such a decline to chaos that enabled ISIS to flourish [2]. 

# Actors #
*[Note these are the decision makers relative to Canada's involvement, not the many players in the complex situation in Syria.  I.e. PM, leader of opposition, advisers, etc]*

# Impacts #
## Relations ##
There is a sense of responsibility to join with our allies in fighting ISIS.  Although there is no clear path toward stability in the Syria-Iraq region, ISIS is universally seen as the most violent and menacing group, and there is a general sense that ISIS must be resisted by countries who have the means.  Failing to engage would probably be seen by our allies as a fairly serious omission and a neglect of our moral duty.

## Impacts in Syria ##
While the expansion of ISIS surely leads to enormous atrocity, there is no clear path to stability in these areas.  The other groups in the region, who vie for power, are almost equally brutal and fighting ISIS tacitly supports these groups.  If ISIS is significantly degraded, it is not clear that people in Syria and Iraq will be any better off, since they face similar treatment by other groups.

## Readiness ##
**Security.** Intervening in this conflict may not be likely to bring it any closer to solution, but it does create new enemies.  By fighting ISIS, we make Canada a target for acts of terrorism.

## Economic ##
Canada's resources, especially militarily, are limited.  A recent report by the Parliamentary Budget Office, finds that the current defense program cannot be sustained without increasing the military budget.  It is not clear that the investment we make in fighting ISIS will have an impact, which questions whether this spending is justified.

fields.title: Canada's involvement in Syria and Iraq
fields.text:
# Actors #

 - **Prime minister of Canada**, Stephen Harper -- is in favor of further involvement in fighting ISIS
 - **Leader of the Official Opposition**, Thomas Mulcair -- believes that we should preferentially spend resources on humanitarian relief, to feed, clothe, and accept refugees, rather than attack ISIS.
 - **President of Syria**, Bashar Al-Assad -- tacitly supports western involvement by allowing the US to conduct airstrikes against ISIS over Syria for six months without confrontation [8].
 - **President of the United States**, Barack Obama -- is leading the fight against ISIS, backed by several Western and Arab allies, including Canada.

# Impacts #
## Relations ##
There is a sense of responsibility to join with our allies in fighting ISIS.  ISIS is universally seen as the most violent and menacing group in the conflict, and there is a general sense that ISIS must be resisted by countries who have the means.  If Canada were to choose not to engage, it would likely be construed as a neglect of moral duty and a failure to follow through on Canada's commitments to its allies.

## Impacts in Syria ##
While the expansion of ISIS surely leads to enormous atrocity, there is no clear path to stability in these areas.    If ISIS is significantly degraded, it is reasonable to expect that the total amount of violence against civilians would be reduced.  However, the other groups in the region, who vie for power, are almost equally brutal, so it is not entirely clear attacking ISIS in Syria will be of significant benefit to Syrians.

## Readiness ##
**Security.** Intervening in this conflict may not be likely to bring it any closer to solution, but it does create new enemies.  By engaging ISIS, Canada becomes a potential target for acts of terrorism.

## Economic ##
Canada's resources, especially militarily, are limited.  A recent report by the Parliamentary Budget Office, finds that the current defense program cannot be sustained without increasing the military budget from 1.1% of GDP (CAD$ 21.5 B) to 1.6% [9].  It is not clear that Canada's investment in fighting ISIS will have a substantial positive impact, which calls to question whether this spending is justified.

# Background #

## ISIS ##
**Origins.** ISIS, the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, also goes by the names ISIL, the Islamic State of Syria and the Levant, and simply IS, Islamic State.  ISIS is a jihadist group that grew in the wake of the Iraq war.  After the US and UK overthrew the oppressive autocrat Saddam Hussein, regional, ethnic, and religious conflicts came to the fore [6].  During the war in Iraq, the US had armed militias to help overthrow Saddam Hussein.  After Saddam Hussein was removed, the militias turned on one another and the US.

ISIS is a splinter group of Al-Qaeda that seeks to create an Islamic state in Iraq.  Instability within Syria has created an opportunity for it take territory there, and now ISIS seeks to take over both Iraq and Syria and create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Quran [3].  ISIS occupies a large territory straddling the border between Iraq and Syria [3].a

**Identity.** ISIS proclaims that it represents Muslims of the world.  In fact, they are shunned by the vast majority of Muslims.  Their identification with Islam is the basis for their legitimacy internally and is used to recruit and radicalize new members.  They use this identity to claim that their enemies have declared war on Islam.

## Conflict in Syria ##
The Syrian Government is headed by president Bashar Al-Assad.  Assad is an oppressive autocrat who has repeatedly used the Syrian army to kill dissenters and protesters.  Under Assad's leadership, the government has bombed its own people, and is alleged to have used chemical weapons on them as well.

The oppressive reign of Assad has led to the emergence of rebel groups that seek to overthrow and replace the government.  The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between rebel groups [10].  The result is a civil without any clear polarity.

Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad's regime are similar in their brutality: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Fighting amongst rebel groups, and between rebel groups and the Syrian government, has caused Syria to descend into chaotic, ungoverned war zone.

This context of instability provides an opportunity to ISIS, to seize territory in Syria and challenge the Syrian government and maligned rebels.  The atrocities commited by ISIS are considered to be the worst, but by some accounts Assad's regime arguably surpasses even ISIS itself [10].  The civil war in Syria has cost tens of thousands of lives [2].

## Canada's initial involvement in Syria ##
**Decision to enter.** In October 2015, after assent by the house of Commons, the government approved the Canadian forces participation in a coalition effort to fight ISIS.  The coalition is US-led, and includes the UK, France, Australia, and many Arab countries [3].  More than 60 countries have joined the coalition [2].  

**Operations.** The coalition operates under the following limits [3]:

 - no ground fighting
 - use airstrikes to attack ISIS positions and disrupt supply lines

However, Canada's Joint Task Force 2, the elite special forces, were involved in training Kurdish soldiers in combat zones[3].  Only the US and its Arab allies have been active in Syria, Canada, and the other western members of the Coalition, have been active only in Iraq [3].

Canada's contribution to the effort consists of 600 soldiers, 6 CF-18s (plus one spare), two Aurora reconnaissance planes, and a Polaris aerial refueller [3].  Since 2 Nov, Canadian forces have flown CF-18s daily in a state of readiness to attack [3; 8].  Within the first two weeks of air operations, Canadian war planes destroyed 2 ISIS targets [1].  

Canadian forces operate under a strict no-civilian casualty policy, and will not strike a target unless the risk of civilian casualties is zero [8].

**Cost.** The first six months of deployment has cost CAD$ 122 M [8].

**Effects.** As of Nov 02 2014, after three months of airstrikes by coalition forces, ISIS appeared undeterred [3].  ISIS Targets have become more difficult to find because they are increasingly hiding among civilian populations, where they are impossible to target without casualties [3].  ISIS has also increasingly shifted its forces to it's western front in Syria, which is outside of Canada's mandate, and that of the other Western allies except the US.  Shortly after Canada joined the effort, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on all
anti-ISIS coalition forces, and specifically named Canada [2].

## Proposed extension of Canada's mandate ##
**Time extension.** Canada's participation in the fight against ISIS would be extended for one year, until March 2016.

**Geographical extension.** The government proposes to extend Canada's mandate to include airstrikes in Syria.

## Prognosis ##
US officials believe the confrontation with ISIS will be a multi-year compaign [3].  The Canadian government's plan has been criticised for a lack of any clear end-game.  It is not clear what it means to "degrade" ISIS, nor how to determine when enough degradation has occurred and when to disengage [5].  As the coalition becomes involved in Syria, they might become increasingly committed, since ceasing involvement would cause a severe shift in the power balance within the conflict, and could have immediate visible consequences to human life.  

Even if ISIS forces are substantiall degraded, there is little reason to believe that the people in Syria will be better off, since power and territory is inevitably transferred from ISIS to the Syrian government and rebel forces [7]. Nevertheless, it seems plausible that, by degrading ISIS forces, the amount of violence inflicted overall in the conflict will be lessened [8].


## The case for intervention ##
Some people argue that earlier intervention in Iraq and Syria could have avoided such a decline to chaos that enabled ISIS to flourish [2].  However past interventions, such as in Iran, Afghanistan, Iraq, and Libya, suggest that there is a consistent pattern of failure in executing interventions [6].  The pattern appears to follow this course [6]: an existing power structure or military agent is identified as being the primary obstacle to freedom and prosperity.  Oppression under this agent has given rise to diverse armed opposition groups that seek to remove the existing structure.  External (Western) forces intervene, and the primary power structure is removed, usually with the help of armed opposition groups.  Once the old power structure is overturned, some of the opposition groups try to step into power.  These groups, being militias, are ill-equipped for the task of governance, which is, of course, completely different from waging of armed warfare.  Meanwhile, there is a lack of civic institutions needed for a functioning democracy [11].  Even when the external agents attempt to scaffold the development of institutions of governance, they are ineffective [11].  The result is the substitution for a regime that is equally oppressive, or a descent into permanent warfare, as various opposition forces vie for power [6].

While the conflict in Syria matches this schema to a degree, in this case, the proposed intervention is *not* to remove an established power structure, but rather, to degrade the encroachment of a violent group that aspires to power, ISIS. Despite the fact that Canada and the US have called for Bashar Al-Assad to resign, the Canadian government has no plan to remove Bashar Al-Assad [1], nor participate in the Syrian conflict in any way other than to assist with strategic attacks on ISIS [1].

Thus, Canadian involvement is strictly to combat, in a highly targeted way, an armed group that is committing terrible crimes against humanity [1].  Given what ISIS is currently doing, and Canada's ability to intervene with airstrikes, it is argued that there is a strong moral imperative to engage.  Furthermore, the Canadian government feels strong pressure from other members of NATO to stay involved and make proportionate contributions to the coalition effort, which is viewed as a humanitarian obligation.

## Threats of terrorism on Canadian soil ##
There have been two attacks on Canadian soldiers while in Canada, at least one of which was directly supported by ISIS recruiting [2].  There is concern that fighting ISIS could make Canada a target for terrorist activities.  Shortly after joining the coalition effort to fight ISIS, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on members of the anti-ISIS coalition, and specifically named Canada.  A number of Canadians are known to be fighting with ISIS, and many are currently trying to go to fight [2].

However, these fears are probably not justified by the actual risks, which, in Canada, are negligible when compared to those directly involved in the conflict.  In 2013, considering all Western nations, there were 12 victims of terror attacks, compared to 22,000 non-Western fatalities, *excluding attacks by the Syrian government on its own people and civilians killed by warfare in Iraq and Afghanistan* [7].

Since October 2014, Canada has been helping allies fight ISIS (the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria), by engaging in airstrikes over Iraq.  Now the government is planning to extend this involvement (originally approved for six months), for an additional year, while expanding its engagement to Syria.

ISIS is an extremely violent, jihadist group, which identifies itself as Sunni Muslim, and seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Quran.

# References #
[1] [CBC, *Canada is at war with ISIS, not Syria, Stephen Harper says*, 14 Nov 
    2014](http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/canada-is-at-war-with-isis-not-syria-stephen-harper-says-1.2834871)

[6] [Globe and Mail, *The expanded Iraq mission is an immoral misadventure*, 27 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/the-expanded-iraq-mission-is-an-immoral-misadventure/article23665816/) 
[7] [Maclean's, *How the Muslim world is being left behind*, 14 January 2015](http://www.macleans.ca/politics/worldpolitics/why-muslim-world-decline/) 
[8] [Globe and Mail, *Tories say waging war on Islamic State is a humanitarian effort*, 26 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/waging-war-on-islamic-state-necessary-part-of-humanitarian-response-tories-say/article23631702/) 
[9] [Globe and Mail, *Ottawa’s defence costs ‘unsustainable’ over next decade, budget watchdog says*, 26 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ottawas-defence-costs-unsustainable-over-next-decade-budget-watchdog-says/article23630687/) 
[10] [CBC, *Is Canada's ISIS mission ready for Syria's moral maze?*, 30 March 215](http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/is-canada-s-isis-mission-ready-for-syria-s-moral-maze-1.3013094)
fields.summary:
Since October 2014, Canada has been helping allies fight ISIS (the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria), by engaging in airstrikes over Iraq.  Now the government is planning to extend this involvement (originally approved for six months), for an additional year, while expanding its engagement to Syria.

ISIS is an extremely violent, jihadist group, which identifies itself as Sunni Muslim, and seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Quran.

fields.title: Canada's involvement in Syria and Iraq
fields.text:
# Actors #

 - **Prime minister of Canada**, Stephen Harper -- is in favor of further involvement in fighting ISIS, and expanding current operations to Syria [1].
 - **Leader of the Official Opposition**, Thomas Mulcair -- believes that we should preferentially spend resources on humanitarian relief, to feed, clothe, and accept refugees, rather than attack ISIS [8].
 - **President of the United States**, Barack Obama -- is leading the fight against ISIS, backed by several Western and Arab allies, including Canada.
 - **President of Syria**, Bashar Al-Assad -- tacitly supports western involvement by allowing the US to conduct airstrikes against ISIS over Syria for six months without confrontation [8].
 - **ISIS**, Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (also ISIL, Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, and IS, Islamic State) -- a violent splinter group of Al-Qaeda that seeks to take over Syria and Iraq to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Quran [3].

# Impacts #
## Relations ##
ISIS is universally seen as the most violent and menacing group in the conflict in Syria, and there is a general sense that ISIS must be resisted by countries who have the means.  If Canada were to choose not to engage, it would likely be construed as a neglect of moral duty and a failure to follow through on Canada's commitments to its allies.

## Impacts in Syria ##
While the expansion of ISIS surely leads to enormous atrocity, there is no clear path to stability in these areas.  If ISIS is significantly degraded, it is reasonable to expect that the total amount of violence against civilians would be reduced.  However, the other groups in the region, who vie for power, are almost equally brutal, so attacking ISIS in Syria may not be of significant benefit to Syrians.

## Readiness ##
**Security.** By engaging ISIS, Canada may become a potential target for acts of terrorism.

## Economic ##
A recent report by the Parliamentary Budget Office, finds that the current defense program cannot be sustained without increasing the military budget from 1.1% of GDP (CAD$ 21.5 B) to 1.6% [9].  It is not clear that Canada's investment in fighting ISIS will have a substantial positive impact, which calls to question whether this spending is justified.

# Background #

## ISIS ##
**Origins.** ISIS, the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, also goes by the names ISIL, the Islamic State of Syria and the Levant, and simply IS, Islamic State.  ISIS is a jihadist group that grew in the wake of the Iraq war.  After the US and UK overthrew the oppressive autocrat Saddam Hussein, regional, ethnic, and religious conflicts came to the fore [6].  During the war in Iraq, the US had armed militias to help overthrow Saddam Hussein.  After Saddam Hussein was removed, the militias turned on one another and the US.

ISIS is a splinter group of Al-Qaeda that seeks to create an Islamic state in Iraq.  Instability within Syria has created an opportunity for it take territory there, and now ISIS seeks to take over both Iraq and Syria and create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Quran [3].  ISIS occupies a large territory straddling the border between Iraq and Syria [3].

**Identity.** ISIS proclaims that it represents Muslims of the world.  In fact, ISIS is shunned by the vast majority of people of all religious affiliations, including Muslims in particular.  Their identification with Islam provides an internal basis for legitimacy, and is used to recruit and radicalize new members.  They use this identification to claim that their enemies have declared war on Islam.

## Conflict in Syria ##
The Syrian Government is headed by president Bashar Al-Assad.  Assad is an oppressive autocrat who has repeatedly used the Syrian army to kill dissenters and protesters.  Under Assad's leadership, the government has bombed its own people, and is alleged to have used chemical weapons on them as well.

The oppressive reign of Assad has led to the emergence of rebel groups that seek to overthrow and replace the government.  The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between rebel groups [10].  The result is a civil without any clear polarity.

Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad's regime are similar in their brutality: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Fighting amongst rebel groups, and between rebel groups and the Syrian government, has caused Syria to descend into chaotic, ungoverned war zone.

This context of instability provides an opportunity to ISIS, to seize territory in Syria and challenge the Syrian government and maligned rebels.  The atrocities commited by ISIS are considered to be the worst, but by some accounts Assad's regime arguably surpasses even ISIS itself [10].  The civil war in Syria has cost tens of thousands of lives [2].

## Canada's initial involvement in Syria ##
**Decision to enter.** In October 2015, after assent by the house of Commons, the government approved the Canadian forces participation in a coalition effort to fight ISIS.  The coalition is US-led, and includes the UK, France, Australia, and many Arab countries [3].  More than 60 countries have joined the coalition [2].  

**Operations.** The coalition operates under the following limits [3]:

 - no ground fighting
 - use airstrikes to attack ISIS positions and disrupt supply lines

However, Canada's Joint Task Force 2, the elite special forces, were involved in training Kurdish soldiers in combat zones[3].  Only the US and its Arab allies have been active in Syria, Canada, and the other western members of the Coalition, have been active only in Iraq [3].

Canada's contribution to the effort consists of 600 soldiers, 6 CF-18s (plus one spare), two Aurora reconnaissance planes, and a Polaris aerial refueller [3].  Since 2 Nov 2014, Canadian forces have flown CF-18s daily in a state of readiness to attack [3; 8].  Within the first two weeks of air operations, Canadian war planes destroyed 2 ISIS targets [1].  

Canadian forces operate under a strict no-civilian casualty policy, and will not strike a target unless the risk of civilian casualties is zero [8].

**Cost.** The first six months of deployment has cost CAD$ 122 M [8].

**Effects.** As of Nov 02 2014, after three months of airstrikes by coalition forces, ISIS appeared undeterred [3].  ISIS Targets have become more difficult to find because they are increasingly hiding among civilian populations, where they are impossible to target without casualties [3].  ISIS has also increasingly shifted its forces to it's western front in Syria, which is outside of Canada's mandate, and that of the other Western allies (except the US).  Shortly after Canada joined the effort, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on all
anti-ISIS coalition forces, and specifically named Canada [2].

## Proposed extension of Canada's mandate ##
**Time extension.** Canada's participation in the fight against ISIS would be extended for one year, until March 2016.

**Geographical extension.** The government proposes to extend Canada's mandate to include airstrikes in Syria, whereas previously operations were confined to Iraq.

## Prognosis ##
US officials believe the confrontation with ISIS will be a multi-year compaign [3].  The Canadian government's plan has been criticized internally for a lack of any clear endpoint.  It is not clear what it means to "degrade" ISIS, nor how to determine when enough degradation has occurred and when to disengage [5].  As the coalition becomes involved in Syria, it might become increasingly committed, since its presence becomes an important contribution to the balance of power, the removal of which could have immediate and visible consequences to human life.  

Even if ISIS forces are substantially degraded, the people in Syria may not be better off, since power and territory is inevitably transferred from ISIS to the Syrian government and rebel forces [7]. Nevertheless, it seems plausible that, by degrading ISIS forces, the amount of violence inflicted overall in the conflict will be lessened [8].


## The case for intervention ##
Some people argue that if the recent intervention in Iraq and Syria had been made earlier, it could have avoided such a decline to chaos that enabled ISIS to flourish [2].  However past interventions, such as in Iran, Afghanistan, Iraq, and Libya, point to a consistent pattern of poor outcomes when intervening in similar circumstances [6].  The pattern appears to follow this course [6]: an existing power structure or military agent is identified as being the primary obstacle to freedom and prosperity.  Before intervening, oppression under this agent has given rise to diverse armed opposition groups that seek to remove the existing structure.  External (Western) forces intervene, and the primary power structure is removed, usually with the help of armed opposition groups.  Once the old power structure is overturned, some of the opposition groups try to step into power.  These groups are ill-equipped for the task of governance, which is, of course, completely different from waging of armed warfare.  Meanwhile, there is a lack of civic institutions and needed for a functioning democracy [11].  Even when the external agents attempt to scaffold the development of institutions of governance, they are ineffective [11].  The result is a substitution for a regime that is equally oppressive, or a descent into chronic warfare, as various opposition forces vie for power [6].

While the conflict in Syria matches this schema to a degree, in this case, the proposed intervention is *not* to remove an established power structure, but rather, to degrade an encroaching violent group that aspires to power, ISIS. Despite the fact that Canada and the US have called for Bashar Al-Assad to resign, the Canadian government has no plan to remove Bashar Al-Assad [1], nor to participate in the Syrian conflict in any way other than to assist with strategic attacks on ISIS [1].

Thus, Canadian involvement is strictly to combat, in a highly targeted way, an armed group that is committing terrible crimes against humanity [1].  Given what ISIS is currently doing, and Canada's ability to intervene with airstrikes, it is argued that there is a strong moral imperative to engage.  Furthermore, the Canadian government feels strong pressure from other members of NATO to stay involved and make proportionate contributions to the coalition effort, which is viewed as a humanitarian obligation.

## Threats of terrorism on Canadian soil ##
There have been two attacks on Canadian soldiers while in Canada, at least one of which was directly supported by ISIS recruiting [2].  There is concern that fighting ISIS could make Canada a target for terrorist activities.  Shortly after joining the coalition effort to fight ISIS, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on members of the anti-ISIS coalition, and specifically named Canada.  A number of Canadians are known to be fighting with ISIS, and many are currently trying to go to fight [2].

However, these fears are probably not justified by the actual risks, which, in Canada, are negligible when compared to those directly involved in the conflict.  In 2013, considering all Western nations, there were 12 victims of terror attacks, compared to 22,000 non-Western fatalities, *excluding attacks by the Syrian government on its own people and civilians killed by warfare in Iraq and Afghanistan* [7].

# References #
[1] [CBC, *Canada is at war with ISIS, not Syria, Stephen Harper says*, 14 Nov 
    2014](http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/canada-is-at-war-with-isis-not-syria-stephen-harper-says-1.2834871)  
[2] [CBC, *Should the West stop intervening in the Middle East?*, 24 Oct 2014](http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/should-the-west-stop-intervening-in-the-middle-east-1.2811177)  
[3] [CBC, *Canada's forces face daunting mission against ISIS in Iraq*, 2 Nov 2014](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/canada-s-forces-face-daunting-mission-against-isis-in-iraq-1.2821390)  
[4] *[Duplicate reference removed]* 
[5] [Globe and Mail, *'Moral clarity' aside, Canada's Syria mission lacks an endgame*, 28 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/canada-is-wading-into-murky-territory-with-moral-clarity-argument/article23676865/)  
[6] [Globe and Mail, *The expanded Iraq mission is an immoral misadventure*, 27 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/the-expanded-iraq-mission-is-an-immoral-misadventure/article23665816/)  
[7] [Maclean's, *How the Muslim world is being left behind*, 14 January 2015](http://www.macleans.ca/politics/worldpolitics/why-muslim-world-decline/)  
[8] [Globe and Mail, *Tories say waging war on Islamic State is a humanitarian effort*, 26 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/waging-war-on-islamic-state-necessary-part-of-humanitarian-response-tories-say/article23631702/)  
[9] [Globe and Mail, *Ottawa’s defence costs ‘unsustainable’ over next decade, budget watchdog says*, 26 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ottawas-defence-costs-unsustainable-over-next-decade-budget-watchdog-says/article23630687/)  
[10] [CBC, *Is Canada's ISIS mission ready for Syria's moral maze?*, 30 March 215](http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/is-canada-s-isis-mission-ready-for-syria-s-moral-maze-1.3013094)

The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between rebel groups [10].  The result is a civil without any clear polarity.

Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad's regime are similar in their brutality: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Fighting amongst rebel groups, and between rebel groups and the Syrian government, has caused Syria to descend into chaotic, ungoverned war zone.

This context of instability provides an opportunity to ISIS, to seize territory in Syria and challenge the Syrian government and maligned rebels.  The atrocities commited by ISIS are considered to be the worst, but by some accounts Assad's regime arguably surpasses even ISIS itself [10].  The civil war in Syria has cost tens of thousands of lives [2].

## Canada's initial involvement in Syria ##
**Decision to enter.** In October 2015, after assent by the house of Commons, the government approved the Canadian forces participation in a coalition effort to fight ISIS.  The coalition is US-led, and includes the UK, France, Australia, and many Arab countries [3].  More than 60 countries have joined the coalition [2].  

**Operations.** The coalition operates under the following limits [3]:

 - no ground fighting
 - use airstrikes to attack ISIS positions and disrupt supply lines

However, Canada's Joint Task Force 2, the elite special forces, were involved in training Kurdish soldiers in combat zones[3].  Only the US and its Arab allies have been active in Syria, Canada, and the other western members of the Coalition, have been active only in Iraq [3].

Canada's contribution to the effort consists of 600 soldiers, 6 CF-18s (plus one spare), two Aurora reconnaissance planes, and a Polaris aerial refueller [3].  Since 2 Nov 2014, Canadian forces have flown CF-18s daily in a state of readiness to attack [3; 8].  Within the first two weeks of air operations, Canadian war planes destroyed 2 ISIS targets [1].  

Canadian forces operate under a strict no-civilian casualty policy, and will not strike a target unless the risk of civilian casualties is zero [8].

**Cost.** The first six months of deployment has cost CAD$ 122 M [8].

**Effects.** As of Nov 02 2014, after three months of airstrikes by coalition forces, ISIS appeared undeterred [3].  ISIS Targets have become more difficult to find because they are increasingly hiding among civilian populations, where they are impossible to target without casualties [3].  ISIS has also increasingly shifted its forces to it's western front in Syria, which is outside of Canada's mandate, and that of the other Western allies (except the US).  Shortly after Canada joined the effort, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on all
anti-ISIS coalition forces, and specifically named Canada [2].

## Proposed extension of Canada's mandate ##
**Time extension.** Canada's participation in the fight against ISIS would be extended for one year, until March 2016.

**Geographical extension.** The government proposes to extend Canada's mandate to include airstrikes in Syria, whereas previously operations were confined to Iraq.

## Prognosis ##
US officials believe the confrontation with ISIS will be a multi-year compaign [3].  The Canadian government's plan has been criticized internally for a lack of any clear endpoint.  It is not clear what it means to "degrade" ISIS, nor how to determine when enough degradation has occurred and when to disengage [5].  As the coalition becomes involved in Syria, it might become increasingly committed, since its presence becomes an important contribution to the balance of power, the removal of which could have immediate and visible consequences to human life.  

Even if ISIS forces are substantially degraded, the people in Syria may not be better off, since power and territory is inevitably transferred from ISIS to the Syrian government and rebel forces [7]. Nevertheless, it seems plausible that, by degrading ISIS forces, the amount of violence inflicted overall in the conflict will be lessened [8].


## The case for intervention ##
Some people argue that if the recent intervention in Iraq and Syria had been made earlier, it could have avoided such a decline to chaos that enabled ISIS to flourish [2].  However past interventions, such as in Iran, Afghanistan, Iraq, and Libya, point to a consistent pattern of poor outcomes when intervening in similar circumstances [6].  The pattern appears to follow this course [6]: an existing power structure or military agent is identified as being the primary obstacle to freedom and prosperity.  Before intervening, oppression under this agent has given rise to diverse armed opposition groups that seek to remove the existing structure.  External (Western) forces intervene, and the primary power structure is removed, usually with the help of armed opposition groups.  Once the old power structure is overturned, some of the opposition groups try to step into power.  These groups are ill-equipped for the task of governance, which is, of course, completely different from waging of armed warfare.  Meanwhile, there is a lack of civic institutions and needed for a functioning democracy [11].  Even when the external agents attempt to scaffold the development of institutions of governance, they are ineffective [11].  The result is a substitution for a regime that is equally oppressive, or a descent into chronic warfare, as various opposition forces vie for power [6].

While the conflict in Syria matches this schema to a degree, in this case, the proposed intervention is *not* to remove an established power structure, but rather, to degrade an encroaching violent group that aspires to power, ISIS. Despite the fact that Canada and the US have called for Bashar Al-Assad to resign, the Canadian government has no plan to remove Bashar Al-Assad [1], nor to participate in the Syrian conflict in any way other than to assist with strategic attacks on ISIS [1].

Thus, Canadian involvement is strictly to combat, in a highly targeted way, an armed group that is committing terrible crimes against humanity [1].  Given what ISIS is currently doing, and Canada's ability to intervene with airstrikes, it is argued that there is a strong moral imperative to engage.  Furthermore, the Canadian government feels strong pressure from other members of NATO to stay involved and make proportionate contributions to the coalition effort, which is viewed as a humanitarian obligation.

## Threats of terrorism on Canadian soil ##
There have been two attacks on Canadian soldiers while in Canada, at least one of which was directly supported by ISIS recruiting [2].  There is concern that fighting ISIS could make Canada a target for terrorist activities.  Shortly after joining the coalition effort to fight ISIS, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on members of the anti-ISIS coalition, and specifically named Canada.  A number of Canadians are known to be fighting with ISIS, and many are currently trying to go to fight [2].

However, these fears are probably not justified by the actual risks, which, in Canada, are negligible when compared to those directly involved in the conflict.  In 2013, considering all Western nations, there were 12 victims of terror attacks, compared to 22,000 non-Western fatalities, *excluding attacks by the Syrian government on its own people and civilians killed by warfare in Iraq and Afghanistan* [7].

# References #
 1. [CBC, *Canada is at war with ISIS, not Syria, Stephen Harper says*, 14 Nov 
    2014](http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/canada-is-at-war-with-isis-not-syria-stephen-harper-says-1.2834871)  
 2. [CBC, *Should the West stop intervening in the Middle East?*, 24 Oct 2014](http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/should-the-west-stop-intervening-in-the-middle-east-1.2811177)  
 3.  [CBC, *Canada's forces face daunting mission against ISIS in Iraq*, 2 Nov 2014](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/canada-s-forces-face-daunting-mission-against-isis-in-iraq-1.2821390)  
 4. *[Duplicate reference removed]*  
 5. [Globe and Mail, *'Moral clarity' aside, Canada's Syria mission lacks an endgame*, 28 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/canada-is-wading-into-murky-territory-with-moral-clarity-argument/article23676865/)  
 6. [Globe and Mail, *The expanded Iraq mission is an immoral misadventure*, 27 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/the-expanded-iraq-mission-is-an-immoral-misadventure/article23665816/)  
 7. [Maclean's, *How the Muslim world is being left behind*, 14 January 2015](http://www.macleans.ca/politics/worldpolitics/why-muslim-world-decline/)  
 8. [Globe and Mail, *Tories say waging war on Islamic State is a humanitarian effort*, 26 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/waging-war-on-islamic-state-necessary-part-of-humanitarian-response-tories-say/article23631702/)  
 9. [Globe and Mail, *Ottawa’s defence costs ‘unsustainable’ over next decade, budget watchdog says*, 26 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ottawas-defence-costs-unsustainable-over-next-decade-budget-watchdog-says/article23630687/)  
 10. [CBC, *Is Canada's ISIS mission ready for Syria's moral maze?*, 30 March 215](http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/is-canada-s-isis-mission-ready-for-syria-s-moral-maze-1.3013094)  
 11. [The Economist, *What’s gone wrong with democracy?*, accessed 31 March 2015](http://www.economist.com/news/essays/21596796-democracy-was-most-successful-political-idea-20th-century-why-has-it-run-trouble-and-what-can-be-do)
fields.summary:
Since October 2014, Canada has been helping allies fight ISIS (the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria), by engaging in airstrikes over Iraq.  Now the government is planning to extend this involvement (originally approved for six months), for an additional year, while expanding its engagement to Syria.

ISIS is an extremely violent, jihadist group, which identifies itself as Sunni Muslim, and seeks to take over Iraq and Syria to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Quran.

fields.title: Canada's involvement in Syria and Iraq
fields.text:
# Actors #

 - **Prime minister of Canada**, Stephen Harper -- is in favor of further involvement in fighting ISIS, and expanding current operations to Syria [1].
 - **Leader of the Official Opposition**, Thomas Mulcair -- believes that we should preferentially spend resources on humanitarian relief, to feed, clothe, and accept refugees, rather than attack ISIS [8].
 - **President of the United States**, Barack Obama -- is leading the fight against ISIS, backed by several Western and Arab allies, including Canada.
 - **President of Syria**, Bashar Al-Assad -- tacitly supports western involvement by allowing the US to conduct airstrikes against ISIS over Syria for six months without confrontation [8].
 - **ISIS**, Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (also ISIL, Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, and IS, Islamic State) -- a violent splinter group of Al-Qaeda that seeks to take over Syria and Iraq to create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Quran [3].

# Impacts #
## Relations ##
ISIS is universally seen as the most violent and menacing group in the conflict in Syria, and there is a general sense that ISIS must be resisted by countries who have the means.  If Canada were to choose not to engage, it would likely be construed as a neglect of moral duty and a failure to follow through on Canada's commitments to its allies.

## Impacts in Syria ##
While the expansion of ISIS surely leads to enormous atrocity, there is no clear path to stability in these areas.  If ISIS is significantly degraded, it is reasonable to expect that the total amount of violence against civilians would be reduced.  However, the other groups in the region, who vie for power, are almost equally brutal, so attacking ISIS in Syria may not be of significant benefit to Syrians.

## Readiness ##
**Security.** By engaging ISIS, Canada may become a potential target for acts of terrorism.

## Economic ##
A recent report by the Parliamentary Budget Office, finds that the current defense program cannot be sustained without increasing the military budget from 1.1% of GDP (CAD$ 21.5 B) to 1.6% [9].  It is not clear that Canada's investment in fighting ISIS will have a substantial positive impact, which calls to question whether this spending is justified.

# Background #

## ISIS ##
**Origins.** ISIS, the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, also goes by the names ISIL, the Islamic State of Syria and the Levant, and simply IS, Islamic State.  ISIS is a jihadist group that grew in the wake of the Iraq war.  After the US and UK overthrew the oppressive autocrat Saddam Hussein, regional, ethnic, and religious conflicts came to the fore [6].  During the war in Iraq, the US had armed militias to help overthrow Saddam Hussein.  After Saddam Hussein was removed, the militias turned on one another and the US.

ISIS is a splinter group of Al-Qaeda that seeks to create an Islamic state in Iraq.  Instability within Syria has created an opportunity for it take territory there, and now ISIS seeks to take over both Iraq and Syria and create a unified Islamic state based on a strict interpretation of the Quran [3].  ISIS occupies a large territory straddling the border between Iraq and Syria [3].

**Identity.** ISIS proclaims that it represents Muslims of the world.  In fact, ISIS is shunned by the vast majority of people of all religious affiliations, including Muslims in particular.  Their identification with Islam provides an internal basis for legitimacy, and is used to recruit and radicalize new members.  They use this identification to claim that their enemies have declared war on Islam.

## Conflict in Syria ##
The Syrian Government is headed by president Bashar Al-Assad.  Assad is an oppressive autocrat who has repeatedly used the Syrian army to kill dissenters and protesters.  Under Assad's leadership, the government has bombed its own people, and is alleged to have used chemical weapons on them as well.

The oppressive reign of Assad has led to the emergence of rebel groups that seek to overthrow and replace the government.  The Free Syrian Army is one such group, consisting of defectors from the Syrian Army.  The National Coalition of Syrian Revolution and Opposing Forces, is only nominally united [10]. The BBC estimates that there are up to 1000 different rebel groups in Syria.  Although they have a common goal to overthrow Assad, their are bitter rivalries between rebel groups [10].  The result is a civil without any clear polarity.

Many of the opposition forces fighting Assad's regime are similar in their brutality: certain opposition militia have engaged in torture, the use of child soldiers, and mass killings [10].  Fighting amongst rebel groups, and between rebel groups and the Syrian government, has caused Syria to descend into chaotic, ungoverned war zone.

This context of instability provides an opportunity to ISIS, to seize territory in Syria and challenge the Syrian government and maligned rebels.  The atrocities commited by ISIS are considered to be the worst, but by some accounts Assad's regime arguably surpasses even ISIS itself [10].  The civil war in Syria has cost tens of thousands of lives [2].

## Canada's initial involvement in Syria ##
**Decision to enter.** In October 2015, after assent by the house of Commons, the government approved the Canadian forces participation in a coalition effort to fight ISIS.  The coalition is US-led, and includes the UK, France, Australia, and many Arab countries [3].  More than 60 countries have joined the coalition [2].  

**Operations.** The coalition operates under the following limits [3]:

 - no ground fighting
 - use airstrikes to attack ISIS positions and disrupt supply lines

However, Canada's Joint Task Force 2, the elite special forces, were involved in training Kurdish soldiers in combat zones[3].  Only the US and its Arab allies have been active in Syria, Canada, and the other western members of the Coalition, have been active only in Iraq [3].

Canada's contribution to the effort consists of 600 soldiers, 6 CF-18s (plus one spare), two Aurora reconnaissance planes, and a Polaris aerial refueller [3].  Since 2 Nov 2014, Canadian forces have flown CF-18s daily in a state of readiness to attack [3; 8].  Within the first two weeks of air operations, Canadian war planes destroyed 2 ISIS targets [1].  

Canadian forces operate under a strict no-civilian casualty policy, and will not strike a target unless the risk of civilian casualties is zero [8].

**Cost.** The mission has already costed CAD$ 122 M and it is expected to cost an additional $406 M for the next 12 months. Further extensions or the cost of shutting the mission down would be extra [12].

**Effects.** As of Nov 02 2014, after three months of airstrikes by coalition forces, ISIS appeared undeterred [3].  ISIS Targets have become more difficult to find because they are increasingly hiding among civilian populations, where they are impossible to target without casualties [3].  ISIS has also increasingly shifted its forces to it's western front in Syria, which is outside of Canada's mandate, and that of the other Western allies (except the US).  Shortly after Canada joined the effort, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on all
anti-ISIS coalition forces, and specifically named Canada [2].

## Proposed extension of Canada's mandate ##
**Time extension.** Canada's participation in the fight against ISIS would be extended for one year, until March 2016.

**Geographical extension.** The government proposes to extend Canada's mandate to include airstrikes in Syria, whereas previously operations were confined to Iraq.

## Prognosis ##
US officials believe the confrontation with ISIS will be a multi-year compaign [3].  The Canadian government's plan has been criticized internally for a lack of any clear endpoint.  It is not clear what it means to "degrade" ISIS, nor how to determine when enough degradation has occurred and when to disengage [5].  As the coalition becomes involved in Syria, it might become increasingly committed, since its presence becomes an important contribution to the balance of power, the removal of which could have immediate and visible consequences to human life.  

Even if ISIS forces are substantially degraded, the people in Syria may not be better off, since power and territory is inevitably transferred from ISIS to the Syrian government and rebel forces [7]. Nevertheless, it seems plausible that, by degrading ISIS forces, the amount of violence inflicted overall in the conflict will be lessened [8].


## The case for intervention ##
Some people argue that if the recent intervention in Iraq and Syria had been made earlier, it could have avoided such a decline to chaos that enabled ISIS to flourish [2].  However past interventions, such as in Iran, Afghanistan, Iraq, and Libya, point to a consistent pattern of poor outcomes when intervening in similar circumstances [6].  The pattern appears to follow this course [6]: an existing power structure or military agent is identified as being the primary obstacle to freedom and prosperity.  Before intervening, oppression under this agent has given rise to diverse armed opposition groups that seek to remove the existing structure.  External (Western) forces intervene, and the primary power structure is removed, usually with the help of armed opposition groups.  Once the old power structure is overturned, some of the opposition groups try to step into power.  These groups are ill-equipped for the task of governance, which is, of course, completely different from waging of armed warfare.  Meanwhile, there is a lack of civic institutions and needed for a functioning democracy [11].  Even when the external agents attempt to scaffold the development of institutions of governance, they are ineffective [11].  The result is a substitution for a regime that is equally oppressive, or a descent into chronic warfare, as various opposition forces vie for power [6].

While the conflict in Syria matches this schema to a degree, in this case, the proposed intervention is *not* to remove an established power structure, but rather, to degrade an encroaching violent group that aspires to power, ISIS. Despite the fact that Canada and the US have called for Bashar Al-Assad to resign, the Canadian government has no plan to remove Bashar Al-Assad [1], nor to participate in the Syrian conflict in any way other than to assist with strategic attacks on ISIS [1].

Thus, Canadian involvement is strictly to combat, in a highly targeted way, an armed group that is committing terrible crimes against humanity [1].  Given what ISIS is currently doing, and Canada's ability to intervene with airstrikes, it is argued that there is a strong moral imperative to engage.  Furthermore, the Canadian government feels strong pressure from other members of NATO to stay involved and make proportionate contributions to the coalition effort, which is viewed as a humanitarian obligation.

## Threats of terrorism on Canadian soil ##
There have been two attacks on Canadian soldiers while in Canada, at least one of which was directly supported by ISIS recruiting [2].  There is concern that fighting ISIS could make Canada a target for terrorist activities.  Shortly after joining the coalition effort to fight ISIS, an ISIS spokesman called for attacks on members of the anti-ISIS coalition, and specifically named Canada.  A number of Canadians are known to be fighting with ISIS, and many are currently trying to go to fight [2].

However, these fears are probably not justified by the actual risks, which, in Canada, are negligible when compared to those directly involved in the conflict.  In 2013, considering all Western nations, there were 12 victims of terror attacks, compared to 22,000 non-Western fatalities, *excluding attacks by the Syrian government on its own people and civilians killed by warfare in Iraq and Afghanistan* [7].

# References #
 1. [CBC, *Canada is at war with ISIS, not Syria, Stephen Harper says*, 14 Nov 
    2014](http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/canada-is-at-war-with-isis-not-syria-stephen-harper-says-1.2834871)  
 2. [CBC, *Should the West stop intervening in the Middle East?*, 24 Oct 2014](http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/should-the-west-stop-intervening-in-the-middle-east-1.2811177)  
 3.  [CBC, *Canada's forces face daunting mission against ISIS in Iraq*, 2 Nov 2014](http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/canada-s-forces-face-daunting-mission-against-isis-in-iraq-1.2821390)  
 4. *[Duplicate reference removed]*  
 5. [Globe and Mail, *'Moral clarity' aside, Canada's Syria mission lacks an endgame*, 28 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/canada-is-wading-into-murky-territory-with-moral-clarity-argument/article23676865/)  
 6. [Globe and Mail, *The expanded Iraq mission is an immoral misadventure*, 27 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/the-expanded-iraq-mission-is-an-immoral-misadventure/article23665816/)  
 7. [Maclean's, *How the Muslim world is being left behind*, 14 January 2015](http://www.macleans.ca/politics/worldpolitics/why-muslim-world-decline/)  
 8. [Globe and Mail, *Tories say waging war on Islamic State is a humanitarian effort*, 26 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/waging-war-on-islamic-state-necessary-part-of-humanitarian-response-tories-say/article23631702/)  
 9. [Globe and Mail, *Ottawa’s defence costs ‘unsustainable’ over next decade, budget watchdog says*, 26 March 2015](http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/ottawas-defence-costs-unsustainable-over-next-decade-budget-watchdog-says/article23630687/)
